fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Left Module over R is an additive group M equipped with a function R\times M\to M denoted (r,m)\mapsto r\cdot m called scalar multiplication, such that
For any m_{1},m_{2}\in M and r\in R, we have r(m_{1}+m_{2})=(rm_{1})+(rm_{2})
For any m\in M and r_{1},r_{2}\in R we have (r_{1}+r_{2})m=(r_{1}m)+(r_{2}m)
Associativity of scalar multiplication: For any m\in M and r_{1},r_{2}\in R we have (r_{1}r_{2})m=r_{1}(r_{2}m)
If R is unital, then we call M Unital when for any m\in M we have 1\cdot m=m.
Exercise: Prove these axioms imply 0_{R}\cdot m=0_{M} for any m\in M.
Exercise: Prove or find a counter-example: a left ideal of a ring is a left module over that ring.

Let R be a Ring. A Right Module over R is an additive group M equipped with a function M\times R\to M denoted (m,r)\mapsto m\cdot r called scalar multiplication, such that
For any m_{1},m_{2}\in M and r\in R, we have (m_{1}+m_{2})r=(m_{1}r)+(m_{2}r)
For any m\in M and r_{1},r_{2}\in R we have m(r_{1}+r_{2})=(mr_{1})+(mr_{2})
Associativity of scalar multiplication: For any m\in M and r_{1},r_{2}\in R we have m(r_{1}r_{2})=(mr_{1})r_{2}
If R is unital, then we call M Unital when for any m\in M we have m\cdot 1=m.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: When R is a Commutative Ring, then a right module over R is also usually turned into a Left Module over R by defining left scalar multiplication as just the same result as right scalar multiplication, i.e., for any r\in R and m\in M we have: rm:=mr. In this case, we usually just write scalar multiplication on the left as a matter of convention. Furthermore, we will just speak of "modules over R" for commutative R.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Exercise: Prove or find a counter-example: a right ideal of a ring is a right module over that ring.

fr:title.text: Modules over fields are synonymous with vector spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modules over fields are synonymous with vector spaces

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let M be either a Left Module over \mathbb {F} or a Right Module over \mathbb {F}. Then M is a Vector Space.
Moreover, any vector space over \mathbb {F} is automatically a module over \mathbb {F}.
Consequently, we treat "vector spaces over fields" as synonymous with "modules over fields".

Let R and S be two Rings. Then an (R,S)-Bimodule is an additive group M such that
M is a Left Module over R; and
M is a Right Module over S; and
Compatibility: For all r\in R and s\in S and m\in M, we have (rm)s=r(ms).
Prove or find a counter-example: a two-sided ideal of a ring is a module over that ring.

We will adopt the convention tacitly used in textbooks: when R is a ring, we say M is an R-module to mean it is either a left module over R or a right module over R, and we will also unambiguously write scalar multiplication as if it were a left module over R.

fr:title.text: Ring of polynomials is a module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of polynomials is a module

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let x be a formal variable. Then the ring of polynomials R[x] is a module over R.
Proof idea: We see that R[x] is closed under addition, and it's closed under scalar multiplication.

fr:title.text: Associative rings are modules over themselves

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associative rings are modules over themselves

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be an associative Ring. Then it is a Left Module over itself, and a Right Module over itself. If R is unital, then these modules are unital.
When R is nonassociative, then it is no longer a module over itself.

Let R be a Ring. Let M be a left/right/bi- module over R. We say M is Free if there exists a basis of M, i.e., a set B\subseteq M such that
Spans the module: every element of M is a linear combination of finitely many elements of B, and
Smallest spanning set: there is no proper subset C\subset B such that any element of M can be written as a linear combination of finitely many elements of C.

Let R be an associative Ring. Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. We define the n-Dimensional Free Module to be the left/right/bi- module R^{n} consisting of n-tuples of elements of R equipped with left/right/two-sided scalar multiplication induced by multiplying tuples componentwise \lambda (x_{1},…,x_{n})=(\lambda x_{1},…, \lambda x_{n}) and (x_{1},…,x_{n})\lambda =(x_{1}\lambda ,…,x_{n}\lambda ) for any \lambda \in R and (x_{1},…,x_{n})\in R^{n}.
Moreover, when R is unital, the elements e_{i}\in R^{n} which is zero except in the i^{\text {th}} component form a basis of R^{n}. This means that R^{n} is free when R is unital.

fr:title.text: Criteria for an additive group to be a module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for an additive group to be a module

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M be an additive Abelian group. Let R be a Ring. Then M is a module over R if and only if there exists a ring morphism R\to \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits (M).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Studying R-modules amounts to studying the ring morphism R\to \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits (M). How can we "fit" R "into" \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits (M) is the big question.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: At this point, we have studied two algebraic gadgets (groups and rings), as well as many other gadgets in other fields.
There are common things to look for when we define a "gadget":

html:ul.html:li: Products of gadgets
Sub-gadgets
Quotients of gadgets
Morphisms between gadgets
Isomorphism theorems
Some attempt to classify gadgets

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring, let M be a module. A Submodule of M is a module N such that it's a subgroup N\leq M and N is closed under scalar multiplication:

html:ul.html:li: If M is a left module over R, then for all r\in R and n\in N we have rn\in N
If M is a right module over R, then for all r\in R and n\in N we have nr\in N

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We will continue writing N\leq M to indicate N is a submodule of M, and N\mathrel {<} M if furthermore N is a Proper submodule of M (i.e., N\neq M).

fr:title.text: Sums of submodules are a submodule

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sums of submodules are a submodule

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring, let M be a module over R, let N and K be Submodules of M. Then K+N=\{k+n\in M\mid k\in K,n\in N\} is a submodule of M.
(1) K+N is closed under addition since (k+n)+(k'+n')=(k+k')+(n+n').
(2) 0\in (K+N) which means K+N is a subgroup of M.
(3) For any r\in R and (k+n)\in K + N we see r(k+n)=(rk)+(rn) and rk\in K and rn\in N which implies (rk)+(rn)\in K+N.

fr:title.text: Intersection of submodules is a submodule

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of submodules is a submodule

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring, let M be a module over R, let N and K be Submodules of M. Then K\cap N is a submodule of M.

fr:title.text: IM is a submodule of M

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: IM is a submodule of M

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Proof idea: It's closed under addition (since adding two finite sums of these linear combinations yields yet another finite sum of these linear combinations) and it's closed under scalar multiplication (since multiplying on the left will just change the coefficients a_{i}\in I to ra_{i}\in I, by definition of a left ideal). Hence it's a submodule.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodule criteria
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 10.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let R be a Ring, let M be an R-module, and let N\subseteq M be a subset of M. Then N is a submodule of M if and only if
N\neq \emptyset and
for all r\in R and x,y\in N, we have x+ry\in N.
Let R be a Ring. Let M be a module over R. Let N\leq M be a Submodule of M. Is M/N a module?
We know N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } M is a normal subgroup of the underlying additive Abelian group of M, so the quotient group M/N is well-defined.

We need to check that scalar multiplication is well-defined r(m+N)=(rm)+N. If we change the representative of m+N to m'+N, then m-m'\in N, so there is some n\in N such that m-m'=n. Multiplying by r gives us rm-rm'=rn\in N. Then rm+N=rm'+N, which confirms scalar multiplication is well-defined.
Checking the axioms are "follow your nose"
We define the Quotient Module M/N to be the module over R equipped with the module structure we just described. Proving it satisfies the axioms is "follow your nose".

Let R be a ring, let M and N be modules over R. A Morphism from M to N is a function \varphi \colon M\to N such that
It's a morphism of the underlying Abelian groups \varphi (m_{1}+m_{2})=\varphi (m_{1})+\varphi (m_{2}) for any m_{1},m_{2}\in M; and
It preserves scalar multiplication: for any r\in R and m\in M we have \varphi (rm)=r\varphi (m). We also say that \varphi is R-Linear.
We write \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N) for the set of all morphisms from M to N.
Exercise 1: For any m\in M, we have a function f\colon R\to M defined by f(r)=rm scalar multiplication. When (if ever) is this R-linear?
Exercise 2: For any r\in R, we have a function g\colon M\to M defined by g(m)=rm scalar multiplication. When (if ever) is this R-linear?

fr:title.text: Identity map is a module morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity map is a module morphism

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring and let M be an R-module. Then \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{M}\colon M\to M is a module morphism.

Let R be a ring, let M and N be modules over R. An Isomorphism from M to N is an R-linear mapping \varphi \colon M\to N such that there exists an R-linear mapping \psi \colon N\to M such that \varphi \circ \psi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{N} and \psi \circ \varphi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{M}.
We say M and N Are Isomorphic if there exists an isomorphism M\to N. In this case, we denote this by M\cong N. It forms an equivalence relation.

Let R be a Ring, let M and N be modules over R, let \varphi \colon M\to N be a morphism of modules. We define the Kernel of \varphi to be the submodule \ker (\varphi )\leq M such that for all m\in M we have m\in \ker (\varphi ) if and only if \varphi (m)=0.

Let R be a Ring, let M and N be modules over R, let \varphi \colon M\to N be a morphism of modules. We define the Image of \varphi to be the submodule \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi ) of N such that for all n\in N we have n\in \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi ) if and only if there exists an m\in M such that \varphi (m)=n.
Let R be a Ring, let M and N be modules over R, let \varphi \colon M\to N be a morphism of modules. Then M/\ker (\varphi )\cong \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi ).
Let M be an R-module, let N and K be Submodules of M. Then (N+K) / K\cong N / (N\cap K).
Let M be an R-module, let N and K be Submodules of M. If N\subseteq K, then \frac {M / N}{K / N}\cong M / K.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal property of free modules
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 10.3.6

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a set, let R be a Ring. There exists an R-module F(A) called the Free Module of A such that: for any R-module M and function of sets \varphi \colon A\to M, there exists a unique R-linear map \Phi \colon F(A)\to M such that for all a\in A we have \Phi (a)=\varphi (a) for all a\in A.

Let R be a Ring. Let M be an R-module, let S\subseteq M be a nonempty subset of M. We define the Annihilator of S to be the subset \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(S)=\{r\in R\mid \forall s\in S\ldotp rs=0\}.
If S=\{m\} is a singleton, we often just write \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m):=\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(\{m\}).
When R is not a commutative ring, we speak of "left annihilator" and "right annihilator" depending on if M is a left or right module over R.
Exercise: When (if ever) is \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(S) an ideal of R?

Let R be a Ring, let M be an R-module. We define the Annihilator of M to be the subset \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M) of R equal to \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M):=\{\lambda \in R\mid \forall m\in M\ldotp \lambda m=0\}.
Exercise: Calculate the Annihilator of \mathbb {F}[x,y]/(x^{3}+x^{2}-y^{2}) where \mathbb {F} is some field.

fr:title.text: Annihilator of Module is intersection of all annihilators of each element of the module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Annihilator of Module is intersection of all annihilators of each element of the module

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. Then \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M)=\bigcap _{m\in M}\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m).
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N\leq M be a submodule of M (possibly M=N). We say N is Cyclic if there exists an m\in M such that N=Rm=\{rm\mid r\in R\}.

fr:title.text: Cyclic modules are quotients of ring with annihilator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cyclic modules are quotients of ring with annihilator

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. Then M is cyclic if and only if there exists an m\in M such that M\cong R/\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m).
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. We say M is Irreducible if any submodule N\leq M we have N=0 or N=M.
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. If M is cyclic, then M is cyclic.
Let m\in M be nonzero. Then we can consider the submodule Rm\leq M. It is nonzero. Hence Rm=M by definition of irreducibility.

fr:title.text: Cyclic modules are irreducible iff its annihilator is a maximal ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cyclic modules are irreducible iff its annihilator is a maximal ideal

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a ring, let M be a cyclic R-module. Then M is irreducible if and only if \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a maximal ideal of R.
Let R be any ring. Then there exists an irreducible R-module.

Let R be a ring, M be an R-module, let m\in M be an element of M. We say m is Torsion if its annihilator is nonzero \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m)\neq 0. Specifically, the annihilator contains a non-zero-divisor nonzero element.
Let R be a ring, M be an R-module. We say M is a Torsion Module if every element of M is a Torsion element.

fr:title.text: Rationals modulo integers is a torsion module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rationals modulo integers is a torsion module

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The quotient \mathbb {Q} / \mathbb {Z} is a torsion \mathbb {Z}-module.
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. The Torsion Submodule \mathop {\textrm {Tor}}\nolimits (M) consists of all Torsion elements of M.
When R is commutative, this is actually an R-module.
When R is noncommutative, we need some additional properties imposed on R for \mathop {\textrm {Tor}}\nolimits (M) to be a right R-module.
Let R be a ring, M be an R-module. We say M is Faithful if its annihilator is the trivial ideal: \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M)=(0).
Let R be a ring, M be an R-module. We say M is Torsion-Free if there is no Torsion element of M.

fr:title.text: Not all torsion-free modules are free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not all torsion-free modules are free

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The ideal (2,x)\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }\mathbb {Z}[x] is torsion-free but not free.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Endomorphisms of an Abelian Group form an Abelian Group (and sometimes a module)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring, let M and N be R-modules. Then the following all hold:

html:ol.html:li: The set of R-linear maps \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N) forms an Abelian group.
If R is a Commutative Ring, then \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N) forms an R-module.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Exercise: Prove there is a canonical isomorphism \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(R,M)\cong M. (Hint: \phi \mapsto \phi (1).)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Schur's lemma
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Problem set 5 from Caltech Math 5B Winter 2018

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a ring, let M be a cyclic R-module. Let N be an R-module. Let I be a left ideal of R. Let us write N[I]=\{n\in N\mid \forall a\in I\ldotp an=0\}.

html:ol.html:li: Prove N[I] is closed under addition.
Let M\cong Rm for some nonzero m\in M. Prove \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N)\cong N[\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m)] as Abelian groups.
Schur's Lemma: If M is irreducible, then \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a division ring.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Now assume further that R is commutative, but everything else remains the same (M is a cyclic R-module, etc.).

html:ol.html:li: Prove N[I] is a submodule of N
Prove \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{R}(M,N)\cong N[\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(m)] as R-modules.
If R is irreducible, then \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a division ring containing in its center the field F=R/\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M).

fr:title.text: Not everything we write down is a module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not everything we write down is a module

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring. Let M be a module over R. Using the notation from exercises on Schur's lemma, prove or find a counter-example for each of these claims:

html:ol.html:li: If \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a left ideal of R, then M[\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M)] is an Abelian subgroup of M but not a submodule of M.
If \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M) is a two-sided ideal of R, then M[\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M)] is a submodule of M.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The moral of this exercise is that we should be thinking of modules in terms of mappings.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let A\subseteq M be a subset of M. Then the Submodule Generated by A is the set of all finite linear combinations RA:=\{\sum _{\text {finite}}r_{i}a_{i}\mid r_{i}\in R,a_{i}\in A\}. This is a submodule of M.

Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N be a submodule of M (possibly N=M), let A\subseteq M be a subset of M. If N=RA, then we call A a Set of Generators (or Generating Set) for N, and we say N is Generated by A.
Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N be a submodule of M (possibly N=M). We say N is Finitely-Generated if there is a finite subset A\subseteq M such that N=RA.

fr:title.text: Finitely-generated modules are not all free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finitely-generated modules are not all free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finitely-generated module with relations among generators is not free

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We may want to think of a generating set as synonymous with a Basis of vector space, but this is incorrect when the generating set has relations among the generators.

For example, let \mathbb {F} be a Field, then we could look at R=\mathbb {F}[x,y] as a ring and M=\mathbb {F}[x,y]/(x^{3}+x^{2}-y^{2}) as an R-module where scalar multiplication is given by the canonical morphism and multiplication in M as a ring. Then M is finitely-generated but not free.

Let R be a ring, let M be a module. Then M is finitely-generated if and only if there exists an n\in \mathbb {N} and a surjective R-linear mapping \varphi \colon R^{n}\to M. Furthermore, if \varphi is an isomorphism, then M is free.

Let R be a Ring. Let M and N be R-modules. We define the Product Module M\oplus N to consist of the Abelian group M\times N equipped with scalar multiplication \begin {split}&R\times (M\oplus N)\to M\oplus N\\ &(r,(m,n))\mapsto r\cdot (m,n)=(rm,rn)\end {split} Note: this is also called the External Direct Sum of M and N.

Proof idea: We need to check this is a well-defined term. Existence and uniqueness are obvious, but we still need to prove this is actually an R-module. So we need to prove the distributivity axioms, associativity of scalar multiplication, and the unit condition 1\cdot (m,n)=(m,n).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Products and Direct Sums of Infinitely many modules

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The direct sum and product of finitely many R-modules describe the same thing.

When we have an infinite family of R-modules \{M_{i}\}_{i\in \mathbb {N}}, they are different. The product \prod _{i\in \mathbb {N}}M_{i} describes all possible formal linear combinations, whereas the direct sum \bigoplus _{i\in \mathbb {N}}M_{i} describes only finite linear combinations.
This should ring a bell, reminding the reader of the Direct sum of groups and the Product of family of groups.

If x_{j}\in I for each j=1,…,m, then we see that \begin {pmatrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots \\ x_{m}\end {pmatrix}\mapsto \begin {pmatrix}y_{1} = \sum _{j}a_{1,j}x_{j}\\ \vdots \\ y_{n}=\sum _{j}a_{n,j}x_{j}\end {pmatrix}, and we know y_{j}\in I for j=1,…,n. fr:title.text: If quotient module is free, then a complement submodule exists

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: If quotient module is free, then a complement submodule exists

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module, let N\leq M be a submodule of M. If M/N is free, then there exists an R-module T such that M\cong N\oplus T.

Look at the canonical map \pi \colon M\twoheadrightarrow M/N where \ker (\pi )\cong N. We want to find a \psi \colon M/N\to M such that \pi \circ \psi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{M/N}. Then the image of \psi (M/N)=T.
(1) Since M/N is free, we can always find such a \psi . To see this, let \{e_{i}\} be a basis of M/N, then \pi (\psi (e_{i}))=e_{i} for each i.
(2) T=\psi (M / N) is such a complement. We just need to check T\cap N=\emptyset , which is an exercise.

fr:title.text: When is a module the direct sum of a free module and its torsion?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: When is a module the direct sum of a free module and its torsion?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a ring, let M be an R-module. When (if ever) can we write M=F\oplus T where F is free and T is the torsion submodule?
Well, we need T=\mathop {\textrm {Tor}}\nolimits (M) such that M/T is free. But not all torsion-free modules are free.
We need R to be a Principal Ideal Domain and M to be finitely-generated, then we obtain the result.

fr:title.text: Torsion-free finitely-generated modules over PIDs are free

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Torsion-free finitely-generated modules over PIDs are free

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain and let M to be finitely-generated R-module. If M is torsion-free, then M is free.
(1) If I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R, then I is a free module over R. Moreover, there exists an a\in I such that I=(a)=Ra\cong R.
(2) If M\leq R^{n} and n\geq 1, then M is free.

fr:title.text: Submodules of a rank n free module over a PID are free and have rank less than or equal to n

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodules of a rank n free module over a PID are free and have rank less than or equal to n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 12.1.4

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be an R-module. If M\leq R^{n} is free, then M is free and the rank of M is bounded as \mathop {\textrm {rank}}\nolimits (M)\leq n.
By induction on n. The base case is trivial.

The inductive case, we write R^{n}=R^{n-1}\oplus R and take F_{0}=R^{n-1}. Then M\cap F_{0}\subseteq M. Let us call this M_{0}=M\cap F_{0}. By induction M_{0} is free, finitely-generated of rank at most n-1.
If M=M_{0}, then we're done.

If M\neq M_{0}, then we have to consider some element of R which generates the rest of M. We look at I=\{\alpha \mid \alpha e_{n}+f_{0}\in M,f_{0}\in F_{0}\}, and the claim is that I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is a nonzero ideal. This is because I=(0) iff M\subseteq F_{0}. So I\neq (0) is generated by a single nonzero element (since R is a principal ideal domain), say I=(\gamma ). Then M=M_{0}\oplus R\omega where \omega =e_{n}\gamma +f\in M.

fr:title.text: Submodules of finitely-generated modules are finitely-generated

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodules of finitely-generated modules are finitely-generated

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module, let N\leq M be a submodule of M. Then N is finitely-generated.
Exercise: Does this work if R is just an Integral domain?

Since M is finitely-generated, there is a surjective morphism \pi \colon R^{n}\to M. Then look at N_{0}:=\pi ^{-1}(N)\leq R^{n}, and \pi |_{N_{0}}\colon N_{0}\twoheadrightarrow N is surjective. Since R is a Principal Ideal Domain, N_{0} is free of rank less than or equal to n, and N is finitely-generated.

fr:title.text: Modules over PIDs are torsion-free iff isomorphic to a submodule of a free module

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modules over PIDs are torsion-free iff isomorphic to a submodule of a free module

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Then M is torsion-free if and only if R is isomorphic to a submodule of a free module.
(\Longleftarrow ) Any submodule of a free module over an integral domain is torsion-free.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume M is torsion-free. Let S be the set of all linearly-independent subsets of M. We can check that S is nonempty (since M being torsion-free and R being an integral domain that \{m\} is linearly independent for any m\in M nonzero m\neq 0) and all ascending chains in S admit an upper bound. Then by Zorn's lemma there exists a maximal element in S. That is to say, there exists a maximal free submodule F of M.

We claim that M/F is torsion. If m+F\in M is not torsion, then the submodule Rm+F of M is free and it properly contains F. Since M is assumed to be torsion free, Rm is free and thus it suffices to check Rm\cap F=(0). But rm\in F iff r(m+F)=0. Since M is finitely-generated then M/F is finitely-generated and torsion. Then there exists some a\in R nonzero a\neq 0 such that a(M/F)=0. Equivalently aM\subseteq F. Since M is torsion-free, M is isomorphic to aM.

fr:title.text: Finite-rank modules over PIDs are direct sums of free and torsion modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite-rank modules over PIDs are direct sums of free and torsion modules

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Then there exists a free finitely-generated R-module F and a finitely-generated torsion R-module T such that M=T\oplus F.
Let T=\mathop {\textrm {Tor}}\nolimits (M). Since R is a commutative integral domain, T is a submodule of M.

Claim: M/T is torsion-free. For any m\in M we see r(m+T)=T implies rm\in T. Since T is torsion, there exists a nonzero a\in R such that a(rm)=0. Since R is an integral domain, we deduce that m is torsion and m+T=T.

Then by Modules over PIDs are torsion-free iff isomorphic to a submodule of a free module and Submodules of a rank n free module over a PID are free and have rank less than or equal to n we deduce M/T is free of finite rank. Then If quotient module is free, then a complement submodule exists implies the result.

fr:title.text: Fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Then the following all hold:

html:ol.html:li: We have M\cong \bigoplus R/(p_{j}^{\alpha _{j}}) where each p_{j} are prime and \alpha _{j}\in \mathbb {N}.
We have M\cong \bigoplus R/(m_{j}) where m_{1}\mathrel {\bigm |} m_{2} and m_{2}\mathrel {\bigm |} m_{3} and ….

fr:mainmatter.html:p: (1) The first claim, viewed as Abelian groups, holds "on the nose" (i.e., we have equality of the underlying Abelian groups).
(2) The second claim is when we want to consider if our module is cyclic, or if we want to consider the annihilator of M.

We can see the equivalence of the two claims writing m_{r}=\prod p^{\alpha _{p,r}} and if m_{i}\mathrel {\bigm |} m_{r} then m_{i}=\prod p^{\alpha _{p,i}} for \alpha _{p,i}\leq \alpha _{p,r}. The Abstract Chinese Remainder Theorem gives us R/m\cong \bigoplus _{p}R/p^{\alpha _{p}}. Then we can convert the summands from one form to the other, and reorder as needed. Also note if p_{1}\neq p_{2}, then these give us Comaximal ideals.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: p-Primary Component
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 12.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Let p be a prime element of R. Then a p-Primary Component of M is a submodule M(p) of M such that:
M=\bigoplus _{p}M(p), and
If M=M(p), then M=\bigoplus _{i}^{m}R/p^{\alpha _{i}}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We have two conditions: either M(p)=\{x\in M\mid p^{r}x=0,r\geq 0\}, or M[p^{r}]=\{x\in M\mid p^{r}x=0\} where p^{r}\mathrel {\bigm |}\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This follows immediately from the Fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs and the fact that Abelian groups are \mathbb {Z}-modules.

fr:title.text: Canonical forms of matrices from fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Canonical forms of matrices from fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We should observe that if \mathbb {F} is a field, then \mathbb {F}[x] is a principal ideal domain. The idea is that if we have a linear operator L\colon M\to M where M is a finitely-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}, then M is a finitely-generated module over \mathbb {F}[x] where x acts on M as described by L.
Then the decomposition of M as a finitely-generated module over \mathbb {F}[x] into a direct sum of submodules gives us a decomposition of L into a block diagonal matrix.
Depending on which form of the fundamental theorem we use, we end up with two different decompositions of L into either the rational canonical form or the Jordan canonical form.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is also kind of a convoluted application of the fundamental theorem. Marc van Leeuwen gave a simpler derivation of the rational canonical form of a matrix without this convoluted dependence on the fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over principal ideal domains.

fr:title.text: \FF [x]-modules are \FF -vector spaces equipped with an endomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: \FF [x]-modules are \FF -vector spaces equipped with an endomorphism

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Let M be a module over \mathbb {F}[x]. Then M is a vector space over \mathbb {F} equipped with an endomorphism \alpha \colon M\to M defined by \alpha (m)=x\cdot m for any m\in M.
This follows from the Fundamental theorem of finitely-generated modules over PIDs.
(1) We see V is a finitely-generated torsion module over \mathbb {F}[x] if and only if V is a finite-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}.

(2) If we have two square n\times n matrices A, B over \mathbb {F}, then they correspond to endomorphisms on an n-dimensional vector space over \mathbb {F}. These give us modules over \mathbb {F}[x] describing the action of x. Then A is similar to B if and only if the corresponding modules over \mathbb {F}[x] are isomorphic.
Let \mathbf {M} be a n\times n matrix over the reals (or some Field). We define the Characteristic Polynomial of \mathbf {M} to be the polynomial p(\lambda )=\det (\mathbf {A}-\lambda \mathbf {I}).

Why is this a good notion? Well, with the eigenstuff for a matrix \mathbf {M}v=\lambda v we have \mathbf {M}v-\lambda v=0. But this is really (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})v=0. Then \mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I} is a linear operator, and we're looking for its kernel. The kernel is nontrivial if the determinant is zero, which means we want to find the values \lambda such that \det (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})=0. But this is precisely the characteristic polynomial as we have defined it.

fr:title.text: Characteristic polynomial of a matrix is monic

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characteristic polynomial of a matrix is monic

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let A be a matrix over \mathbb {F}. Then the characteristic polynomial c_{A}(x) of A is a monic polynomial in x.

The leading term of c_{A}(x) is given by the diagonal contribution to the determinant is (up to a factor of \pm 1), f(x)=\prod ^{n}_{j=1}(x-a_{j,j}) and all other contributions are lower-order terms. When we expand f(x) out, we see it is monic, and adding a lower-order polynomial to a monic polynomial is monic.

Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Let X\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix over \mathbb {F}. Let I_{X}=\{p\in \mathbb {F}[x]\mid p(X)=0\}, where p(X)=0 is the zero matrix, and we see I_{X} is a proper ideal of the principal ideal domain \mathbb {F}[x]. Then there exists a unique monic polynomial m_{X}(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] such that I_{X}=(m_{X}(x)). We call this m_{X}(x) the Minimal Polynomial of X.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It's not hard to see that the minimal polynomial is the unique monic polynomial which generates the Annihilator of a module \mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits (V) in \mathbb {F}[x].

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a monic polynomial f(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}. Then the Companion Matrix of f(x) is the n\times n matrix over \mathbb {F} denoted C_{f(x)} (or C_{f}) consisting of 1 on the lower subdiagonal, the last column is (C_{f})_{n,i}=-b_{i-1}. All other components are zero, so it generically looks like: C_{f} = \begin {pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 & … & 0 & -b_{0}\\ 1 & 0 & 0 & … & 0 & -b_{1}\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & … & 0 & -b_{2}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & … & 1 & -b_{n-1}\end {pmatrix}

fr:title.text: Characteristic polynomial of a companion matrix is the monic polynomial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characteristic polynomial of a companion matrix is the monic polynomial

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a nonconstant monic polynomial. Then the characteristic polynomial of the companion matrix of f(x) is equal to f(x), i.e., c_{C_{f}}(x)=f(x).

We can write down \det (Ix - C_{f}) = \left |\begin {matrix}x & 0 & 0 & … & a_{0}\\ -1 & x & 0 & … & a_{1}\\ 0 & -1 & x & … & a_{2}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & … & -1 & x + a_{n-1}\end {matrix}\right | We can add x times the last row to the previous row, and then add x times that resulting row to the previous row, and so on, and we get (since the determinant is invariant under elementary row operations), \det (Ix - C_{f}) = \left |\begin {matrix}0 & 0 & 0 & … & f(x)\\ -1 & 0 & 0 & … & *\\ 0 & -1 & 0 & … & *\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & … & -1 & *\end {matrix}\right | We see this is equal to \begin {align*}\det (Ix-C_{f})&=(-1)^{\deg (f)-1}f(x)\left |\begin {matrix}-1 & & \\ & \ddots & \\ & & -1\end {matrix}\right |\\ &=(-1)^{\deg (f)-1}f(x)\det (-I_{\deg (f)-1})\\ &=(-1)^{\deg (f)-1}f(x)(-1)^{\deg (f)-1}\\ &=f(x).\end {align*} Hence the result.

Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let X\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix, let V=\mathbb {F}^{n} be a free vector space over \mathbb {F}. We can decompose V=V_{1}\oplus …\oplus V_{m} where each V_{i} is an Invariant subspace under X and the dimension \dim (V_{1})=\deg (m_{X}(x)) is the degree of the minimal polynomial of X and \dim (V_{i})\leq \dim (V_{i+1}).

Moreover, there is a basis (e_{1},…,e_{n}) of V such that the first \dim (V_{1}) span V_{1}, then first \dim (V_{1}\oplus V_{2}) span V_{1}\oplus V_{2}, and so on; and X with respect to this basis may be written in block form as X = \begin {pmatrix} C_{f_{1}} & 0 & … & 0\\ 0 & C_{f_{2}} & … & 0\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & … & C_{f_{m}}\end {pmatrix} where C_{f_{1}} is the Companion Matrix of the minimal polynomial f_{1} of X, and C_{f_{2}}, …, C_{f_{m}} are the companion matrices of monic polynomials f_{2}, …, f_{m} which are called the Invariant Factors. Moreover f_{j+1}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} f_{j}(x) for each j=1,…,m-1.

fr:title.text: Rational Canonical Form of a Matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rational Canonical Form of a Matrix

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let X\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix over \mathbb {F}. The Rational Canonical Form of X is the block diagonal matrix consisting of companion matrices of the invariant factors of X.
We will write \mathop {\textrm {RCF}}\nolimits (X) for the rational canonical form matrix of X.

fr:title.text: Matrices are similar iff they have the same rational canonical form

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrices are similar iff they have the same rational canonical form

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let A\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) be an n\times n matrix over \mathbb {F}. Let c_{A}(x)=\det (x I_{n}-A) be the characteristic polynomial of A, and let m_{A}(x) be the minimal polynomial of A. Then the minimal polynomial of A divides the characteristic polynomial for the matrix m_{A}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} c_{A}(x). Moreover there exists an m\in \mathbb {N} such that c_{A}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} m_{A}(x)^{m}, where m is the number of invariant factors of X.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: An immediate consequence of this is that c_{A}(A)=0 is the zero matrix, since m_{A}(A)=0 and m_{A}(x)\mathrel {\bigm |} c_{A}(x). Usually, C_{A}(A)=0 is the result known as the Cayley-Hamilton theorem.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For this particular case, it turns out A\sim _{\mathbb {Q}}B\iff A\sim _{\mathbb {C}}B. This is called Stable Conjugacy. This is a consequence of version (1) of the fundamental theorem of modules over principal ideal domains...and why the Rational Canonical Form of a Matrix is so important. A matrix in rational canonical form over \mathbb {Q} is also in rational canonical form over \mathbb {C}, and then we use the fact Matrices are similar iff they have the same rational canonical form.

Let R=\mathbb {C}[x] (or if \mathbb {F} is any algebraically closed field, then we could also consider R=\mathbb {F}[x]). Now, we need to list all irreducible elements of R (which is why we need coefficients in an algebraically closed field: the irreducible elements all look like x-\lambda for some \lambda \in \mathbb {C}).

We have the eigenvalues \lambda _{1}, …, \lambda _{n}. The invariant factors f_{1}(x), …, f_{m}(x) of a matrix A factors completely in the sense that f_{j}(x)=\prod ^{n}_{i=1}(x-\lambda _{i})^{\alpha _{j}(\lambda _{i})} where \alpha _{j}(\lambda _{i}) is the multiplicity of eigenvalue \lambda _{i} in the invariant factor f_{j}. We see that for any i we have \alpha _{1}(\lambda _{i})\geq \alpha _{2}(\lambda _{i})\geq …\geq \alpha _{m}(\lambda _{j}) since f_{k}\mathrel {\bigm |} f_{j} for any k\geq j. This means \mathop {\textrm {JCF}}\nolimits (A)=\bigoplus ^{n}_{i}\left (\bigoplus ^{m}_{j=1}J_{\alpha _{j}(\lambda _{i})}(\lambda _{i})\right ) where J_{\alpha _{j}(\lambda )}(\lambda ) is the Jordan block of size \alpha _{j}(\lambda ) with eigenvalue \lambda .
How does this relate to the decomposition of modules? Well, each Jordan block acts on a cyclic submodule of the form \mathbb {C}[x] / (x-\lambda )^{\alpha (\lambda )}.

Let R be a unital Ring, let \lambda \in R, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. A Jordan Block of size n with eigenvalue \lambda is an n\times n matrix which looks like \begin {pmatrix} \lambda & 1 & & & \\ & \lambda & \ddots & & \\ & & \ddots & 1 & \\ & & & \lambda & 1 \\ & & & & \lambda \end {pmatrix}. That is to say, the upper subdiagonal are all 1, the diagonal entries are all \lambda , and all other entries are zero.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is also called an n\times n elementary Jordan matrix with eigenvalue \lambda , among other various similar terms.

fr:title.text: Criteria for diagonalizability of a matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for diagonalizability of a matrix

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer, let A\in \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {C}) be a complex n\times n matrix. The following are equivalent:

html:ol.html:li: The matrix A is diagonalizable.
There are n distinct eigenvalues of A.
The minimal polynomial factorizes as m_{A}(x)=\prod _{i}(x-\lambda _{i}) where each \lambda _{i} is distinct.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: If A is diagonalizable, then its Jordan Canonical Form consists of 1\times 1 Jordan blocks.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This is loosely following the material covered in the Math 5 series at California Institute of Technology (based on Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra) or the Math 150 series at University of California, Davis (based on Artin's Algebra).
We have already seen a number of different "species" of Mathematical Gadgets, like:

It turns out, all the information which was really interesting was encoded in the "structure-preserving transformations" between them. (That was the bulk of our time spent studying Elementary linear algebra and Intermediate linear algebra, after all!)
We can form an abstraction describing this situation where we have a [gadget] and [transformations] between them: this is category theory.

fr:title.text: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The traditional way we teach undergraduates is by introducing several types of gadgets in abstract algebra in the following order:

html:ol.html:li: Initially, there's some discussion of set theory sufficient for developing algebra. This is "time honored tradition" starting with van der Waerden's book.

When the structure-preserving transformations leave something invariant (e.g., Invariant subspaces in linear algebra), composing such transformations also leaves the thing invariant. This is the guiding intuition of what a "symmetry" is, and the "collection of symmetries" is precisely what a "group" is (originally, they were a "group of symmetries" or a symmetry group).

html:li.html:p: (a) But we also saw how, e.g., square matrices have a neat algebraic structure with matrix addition and matrix multiplication. They act like a "number system". This is precisely what is studied with number ring (or just a Ring). A sufficiently nice ring is a Field.
(b) We can generalize linear algebra to describe "vector spaces over arbitrary rings", and these are modules.

html:ol.html:li: Galois theory is offered as the pinnacle of abstract algebra, connecting group theory to field theory. Honestly, I never understood the excitement behind Galois theory, since the beautiful parts of it are just the representation theory of groups (describing how "the same symmetries appearing in different situations").

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This is just the first 7 chapters of van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I. Most textbooks have followed this manner of presentation: Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra covers this material in the first 14 chapters; Hungerford's Algebra does this in the first 6 chapters.

fr:title.text: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The more modern approaches to teaching abstract algebra incorporates some degree of category theory into the mix.

Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter 0 is perhaps the most bold attempt to reorganize abstract algebra around category theory entirely. Instead of ending at Galois theory, Aluffi concludes with homological algebra.
Some ideas from the traditional approach (like "groups with operators") turn out to be confused and muddled (which should be replaced with groups acting on other groups).

If I had to teach abstract algebra to undergraduates, I am torn between the traditional approaches (starting from van der Waerden's Moderne Algebra onwards) which I just outlined, and more modern adaptations which wrap everything in the framework of category theory. Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter Zero seemingly attempts a happy medium, and I am unhappy with it.

One fortunate aspect to Forester is that I'm not forced to choose one or the other. I can outline the "traditional" presentation of topics, and the "modern" presentation of topics, and allow the reader to pick which manner of presentation they wish to peruse.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Well-ordering principle
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Every nonempty subset A\subseteq \mathbb {N} has a minimal element:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall A\subseteq \mathbb {N}\ldotp A\neq \emptyset \implies \exists a\in A\ldotp \forall x\in A\ldotp a\leq x.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Division algorithm
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any integers a,b\in \mathbb {Z}, there exists q,r\in \mathbb {Z} such that 0\leq r<|b| and a=qb+r.
We could take A=\{a-qb\mid q\in \mathbb {Z},a-qb\geq 0\}, then apply the Well-ordering principle to give us r as a minimal element of A.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Greatest common divisor
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If a,b\in \mathbb {Z} are nonzero integers, there exists a unique positive integer called the Greatest Common Divisor of a and b, usually denoted \gcd (a,b), such that:

html:ol.html:li: \gcd (a,b)\mathrel {\bigm |} a and \gcd (a,b)\mathrel {\bigm |} b (so \gcd (a,b) is a common divisor of a and b)
if e\mathrel {\bigm |} a and e\mathrel {\bigm |} b is another integer, then e\mathrel {\bigm |}\gcd (a,b) (so \gcd (a,b) is the greatest such divisor).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If \gcd (a,b)=1 we say a and {b} are Coprime (or are Relatively Prime).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unique prime factorization
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any n\in \mathbb {N}, we may write it as a product n=p_{1}^{\alpha _{1}}(…)p_{k}^{\alpha _{k}} of distinct primes p_{i} and exponents \alpha _{i}\in \mathbb {N}. Here "uniqueness" means if we have another factorization n=q_{1}^{\beta _{1}}(…)q_{\ell }^{\beta _{\ell }}, then k=\ell and we have a bijection \sigma \colon \{1,…,k\}\to \{1,…,\ell \} such that p_{i}=q_{\sigma (i)} and \alpha _{i}=\beta _{\sigma (i)}. In other words, the two factorizations differ only in the ordering of factors.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euler totient
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We have \varphi (n) be the number of positive integers less than n which are coprime to n, \varphi (n)=|\{k\in \mathbb {N}\mid k<n,\gcd (k,n)=1\}|. So \varphi (12)=|\{1,5,7,11\}|=4, but \varphi (11)=10.

fr:title.text: Euler totient is multiplicative on products of coprime numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euler totient is multiplicative on products of coprime numbers

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let m,n\in \mathbb {N} be coprime \gcd (m,n)=1. Prove or find a counter-example: \varphi (mn)=\varphi (m)\varphi (n).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.3

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integers modulo n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a fixed positive integer. Let us define the Equivalence relation on the integers by a\sim b\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(b-a). This is reflexive (a\sim a since n\mathrel {\bigm |}(a-a)), symmetric (a\sim b\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(b-a)\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(a-b)\iff b\sim a) and transitive.
Then the quotient set \mathbb {Z} /\mathord {\sim } is often denoted \mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z}. Moreover, there are well-defined operations [a]+[b]=[a+b] and [a]\cdot [b]=[a\cdot b].

We have implicitly used binary operators when discussion the algebra of matrices, Fields, Vector Spaces, and so on. Some concrete examples include Matrix Addition, Matrix Subtraction, and Matrix Multiplication.
Unary operators have been infrequently mentioned. For example, the Matrix Transpose is a unary operator on the set of matrices.
Tradition dictates we explicitly formalize the notions of binary and unary operators.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a set. A Binary Operator (or, more archaically, Law of Composition) is a function \mu \colon X\times X\to X which is various denoted using infixed notation a\star b or a\cdot b or ab (or, if commutative, a+b) for any a,b\in X.

fr:title.text: Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a set. Then X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) the Set of all functions from A to A has a binary operator, namely Composition of functions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Associative if \forall a,b,c\in X\ldotp \mu (a,\mu (b,c))=\mu (\mu (a,b),c)
Examples of associative binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

html:ul.html:li: If A is a set and X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) is the Set of all functions from A to itself, we know Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions. It turns out that Composing functions is associative.
If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then both addition and multiplication is associative.
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} has Matrix Multiplication is Associative.

fr:mainmatter.html:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} can be equipped with the Commutator which is a binary operator denoted [A,B]=AB-BA for any n\times n matrices A and B over \mathbb {F}. The commutator is not associative, i.e., in general we have [A, [B, C]] \neq [[A,B],C] but it satisfies a variant called the Jacobi Identity: [A, [B, C]] + [B, [C, A]] + [C, [A, B]] = 0 for any n\times n matrices A, B, and C.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Commutative if \forall a,b\in X\ldotp \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)
Examples of commutative binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

html:ul.html:li: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then both addition and multiplication is commutative.
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F}, we see Matrix Addition is Commutative.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Some non-examples:

html:ul.html:li: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F}, we see Matrix Multiplication is not commutative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Let e\in X be an element. We say e is a Unit (or identity element) for \mu if \forall a\in X\ldotp \mu (a,e)=a\land \mu (e,a)=a.

fr:title.text: Examples of identity element for a binary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Examples of identity element for a binary operator

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Examples of identity elements for binary operators we have already seen in Mathematics:

html:ul.html:li: If A is a set and X=\mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (A,A) is the Set of all functions from A to itself, we know Function composition is a binary operator on the set of all functions. It turns out that the Identity function is the identity element for the Composition of functions.
If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then its 0 acts as an identity element for addition and 1 acts as an identity element for multiplication.

Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. Then the set of n\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {F} we see that Multiplying by Identity Matrix acts like an identity element for matrix multiplication; and also Matrix Addition with Zero Matrix has the zero matrix act like the identity element for matrix addition.

fr:title.text: Commutator of matrices has no identity element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutator of matrices has no identity element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Commutator of matrices over a Field \mathbb {F} (or a suitable ring). It turns out, the commutator has no identity element. If it had one, say \mathbf {E}, then for any matrix \mathbf {A} we would have [\mathbf {E},\mathbf {A}]=\mathbf {A} and by anticommutativity of the commutator [\mathbf {A},\mathbf {E}]=-\mathbf {A}. But then we find the Jacobi Identity fails to hold: [\mathbf {E},[\mathbf {B},\mathbf {C}]] + [\mathbf {B}, [\mathbf {C}, \mathbf {E}]] + [\mathbf {C}, [\mathbf {E}, \mathbf {B}]] = [\mathbf {C},\mathbf {B}]\neq 0.

fr:title.text: Identity element is at most unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element is at most unique

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Then there exists at most 1 Identity element for \mu in X.
If e_{1}\in A and e_{2}\in A are two possible identity elements, then e_{1}=\mu (e_{1},e_{2})=e_{2}.

fr:title.text: Inverse of an element with respect to a binary operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of an element with respect to a binary operator

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a set equipped with a Binary operator \mu with an identity element e\in A, let a\in A. A (Two-Sided) Inverse of a is an element b\in A such that \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)=e.

(1) If \mu is an Associative binary operator, then we can just speak of "inverses" of elements without the "two-sided" prefix. This is because the Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique
(2) If there are multiple binary operators on A, then we should specify that b is an inverse of a with respect to \mu .

fr:title.text: Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse with respect to an associative binary operator is unique

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a set, let \mu be an Associative binary operator on A. Let e\in A be the Identity element for \mu . For any element a\in A, there is at most 1 inverse for a with respect to \mu .

Let b_{1},b_{2}\in A be inverses for a. Then \begin {align} b_{1}&=\mu (b_{1},e)\\ &=\mu (b_{1},\mu (a,b_{2}))\\ &=\mu (\mu (b_{1},a),b_{2})\hbox { by associativity}\\ &=\mu (e,b_{2})\\ &=b_{2}.\end {align} Hence the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A Group consists of a set G equipped with an Associative binary operator \star and an Identity element with respect to \star , usually denoted either e\in G or 1\in G, such that every element has a unique inverse, \forall a\in G\ldotp \exists a^{-1}\in A\ldotp a\star a^{-1}=a^{-1}\star a=e.
(1) When the binary operator for the group is commutative, we usually use + for the binary operator and 0 for the identity element.

(2) The "exact formalization" varies. For example, we could have equipped G with a binary operator \star , a unary operator (-)^{-1}\colon G\to G, and a constant element e\in G; this is what we will find useful in category theory later. But they are describing "the same thing". So don't worry about it if you're reading a textbook with a slightly different definition.

(3) The intuition is that G consists of bijections from a set to itself, and the binary operator is just the Composition of functions and the identity element is just the Identity function. These bijections are "symmetries" of the set.
(4) See also Forrester-Barker's Group objects and internal categories for a way to generalize the notion of groups to other settings.

The whole motivation for a group is to describe symmetries, which was usually described using a Left group action. The first application was to study the symmetries of polynomials in an attempt to find roots of polynomials, which culminated in Galois theory.
When we define a Group (or Vector Space or...), we typically have a kind of "template" for the definition which looks like:

html:blockquote.html:p: A Gadget consists of some stuff (sets or other gadgets like fields) equipped with some structure (functions, subsets, subset families like topologies, or specific elements) such that a bunch of properties (usually equations) hold.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: John Baez and James Dolan were the first to explore this template for definitions. See also Sections 2.4 and 3.1 of Baez and Shulman.

Model theorists typically describe this as a tuple (all the "stuff" and "structure" are crammed together into one tuple) which satisfy some axioms (the "properties"). While this is neat, it lacks some of the desired "inheritance" (like a Field really is an Abelian group with addition, extended with a multiplication operator and a "one" element). Computer Scientists would suggest using a "finite map" instead of a tuple.

There is also some tension between "Mathematical Practice" and what is desirable when formalizing concepts in a proof assistant. For example, we would often want to define a group as a group object internal to the category of sets, but that adds a lot of needless complications to formalizing this in a proof assistant (where we would want as Spartan a structure as possible).

fr:title.text: Fields with addition form a commutative group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fields with addition form a commutative group

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Then \mathbb {F} equipped with its addition operation forms a group where the identity element is the zero \in \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Integers form a group under addition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integers form a group under addition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The integers \mathbb {Z} form a group when equipped with addition. The identity element is 0\in \mathbb {Z}. This is another commutative group.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Permutation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. A Permutation \pi of n elements is a bijection from the set \{1,2,…,n\} to itself.
Let X be a set. A Permutation of X is a Bijective function f\colon X\to X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric Group of degree n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. We define the Symmetric Group of degree n to be the set S_{n} of all permutations of n elements equipped with Composition of functions since composing two permutations of n elements is another permutation of n elements.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It's not hard to prove this, indeed, forms a Group.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric group of a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a set. We define the Symmetric Group of X to be the Group \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X) consisting of all permutations on X, equipped with Composition of functions as its Binary operator.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quaternion Group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.5

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We may define the Quaternion Group as consisting of the set Q_{8}=\{-1\}\cup \{i^{m}j^{n}k^{p}\mid 0\leq m,n,p\leq 3\} where we identify 1=i^{0}j^{0}k^{0} and it obeys the identities i^{2}=j^{2}=k^{2}=ijk=-1 and so we write -i=i^{3}, -j=j^{3}, and -k=k^{3}, and also (-1)^{2}=1. We have (-1)i=-i, (-1)j=-j, and (-1)k=-k. After a bit of work, we find ij=-ji=k jk=-kj=i ki=-ik=j

Let A be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator with Identity element e\in A. We define the Set of all invertible elements in A to be the set of all elements with a (two-sided) inverse, A^{\times }=\{a\in A\mid \exists a^{-1}\in A\ldotp \mu (a,a^{-1})=\mu (a^{-1},a)=e\}.

fr:title.text: Set of invertible elements for associative binary operator is a group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of invertible elements for associative binary operator is a group

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let A be a set equipped with an Associative binary operator \mu with an Identity element e\in A. Then the Set of all invertible elements equipped with \mu forms a Group.
We need to show that A^{\times } is closed with respect to \mu , i.e., for any a,b\in A^{\times }, we have \mu (a,b)\in A and also e\in A^{\times }.
Well, we see \mu (e,e)=e which implies e^{-1}=e and therefore e\in A^{\times }.

Let a,b\in A^{\times }. Then we claim \mu (b^{-1},a^{-1}) is the inverse element for \mu (a,b), since \begin {align}\mu (\mu (b^{-1},a^{-1}),\mu (a,b)) &=\mu (b^{-1},\mu (a^{-1},\mu (a,b)))\hbox { by associativity}\\ &=\mu (b^{-1},\mu (\mu (a^{-1},a),b))\hbox { by associativity}\\ &=\mu (b^{-1},\mu (e,b))\\ &=\mu (b^{-1},b)=e,\end {align} and similar reasoning shows \mu (\mu (a,b), \mu (b^{-1},a^{-1}))=e. Hence multiplying two elements of A^{\times } together yields another element in A^{\times }. So we have a group.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: General Linear Group of matrices
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This can be defined more generally replacing \mathbb {F} with a unital (possibly noncommutative) ring R, or even a ringoid (where we don't require additive inverses to exist).

fr:title.text: General Linear group of a vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: General Linear group of a vector space

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field. Let V be a Vector Space over \mathbb {F}. We define the General Linear Group on V to be the group \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits (V) consisting of all invertible linear maps from V to itself, equipped with composition and the identity linear transformation as the identity element.

When we pick an ordered basis B for V and write matrix M(g) relative to B for each linear transformation g\in \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits (V), then we recover the General Linear Group of matrices over \mathbb {F}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dihedral group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. We define the Dihedral group D_{n} to consist of the set \{x^{k}y^{j}\mid 0\leq k<n,0\leq j\leq 1\} where we also write x^{0}y^{0}=1, such that x^{n}=y^{2}=1 and also yx=x^{-1}y. It's not hard to see yx^{k}=x^{-k}y by applying that second relation k times.
(1) The dihedral group describes the symmetries of the regular n-gon in the plane, where x is rotation anticlockwise by 2\pi / n and y is reflection about a line through the origin.
(2) Some authors (like Dummit and Foote) call this group D_{2n} because it is of order 2n.
(3) D_{1} has x=1 and D_{0} is degenerate.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: "Abstract" groups and "group of transformations"
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I, Section 6

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Some older books distinguish 'abstract groups' from 'groups of transformations'. This distinction appears in van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I, Section 6, if not earlier.
Briefly, an 'abstract group' is presented in terms of 'generators' and 'relations'. For example, we did this implicitly when discussing the Quaternion Group and the Dihedral group.

A 'group of transformations' is an automorphism group of a Mathematical object. For example, the General Linear group of a vector space describes the automorphism group of a vector space, the Permutation of a set describes the automorphism group of a set. This is a bit anachronistic as a description, since van der Waerden thought of a group of transformations as "just" bijections of some set.
We should think of an "abstract group" as "just meaningless symbols satisfying some equations", but a "group of transformations" are "concrete realizations" of symmetries "in the wild".
When a Group has a commutative binary operator, we call it an Abelian group (or a Commutative group).
Typically, for Abelian groups, we write the binary operator as addition, and the identity element as 0.

I have grown to believe over the years that an Abelian group should be reserved for a generalization of a Vector Space if we just forget about scalar multiplication and the field. This is how most proof assistants handle it.
Commutative groups are groups which are, well, equipped with a Commutative binary operator.

Let G be a Group, let g\in G, let n\in \mathbb {N}_{0} be a non-negative integer. We write g^{n} and define it inductively by g^{0}=e and g^{n+1}=g\star g^{n}. We can extend this to integer exponents by defining g^{-n}=(g^{-1})^{n}.
Let G be a Group, let g\in G, let m,n\in \mathbb {Z}. Then g^{m}g^{n}=g^{m+n}.
By induction on n.
Base case: n=0. We see g^{m}g^{0}=g^{m}e=g^{m}=g^{m+n}.

Inductive case: Assume the inductive hypothesis g^{m}g^{n}=g^{m+n} for arbitrary n\in \mathbb {Z}. We want to show g^{m}g^{n+1}=g^{m+n+1} and also g^{m}g^{n-1}=g^{m+n-1}, but this follows by the inductive hypothesis and associativity.
Let G be a Group, let g\in G, let m,n\in \mathbb {Z} be integers. Then (g^{m})^{n}=g^{mn}.
Divide this up into the four cases where m\geq 0 or -m>0 (i.e,, m<0), and separately n\geq 0 or -n>0 (i.e., n<0). It's useful to note g^{-m}=(g^{-1})^{m}=(g^{m})^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Cyclic subgroup generated by an element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cyclic subgroup generated by an element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group and let g\in G. Then we define the Cyclic subgroup generated by g to be the commutative group \langle g\rangle whose underlying set is \{g^{n}\mid n\in \mathbb {Z}\}.
We need to prove this is actually a group and it is commutative.

Claim 1: it is a group. Suffices to show the binary operator of G is closed on this set and e\in G and it contains all its inverses. The binary operator of G is clearly closed on this set by the Product law and g^{0}=e so the identity element belongs to it. Further, if g^{n}\in \langle g\rangle , then its inverse g^{-n}\in \langle g\rangle clearly belongs to it. Hence this is really a group.
Claim 2: it is commutative. We see for any arbitrary g^{m}g^{n}=g^{m+n}=g^{n+m}=g^{n}g^{m} by the Product law and the commutativity of addition for integers.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Order of a group element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let g\in G. We define Order of g is the integer \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g) equal to either the smallest positive integer n\in \mathbb {N} such that g^{n}=e or if no such positive integer exists, it is defined to be zero.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Some authors prefer \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g) to be infinite if there is no smallest positive integer n such that g^{n}=e, but it can complicate some results.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. We define the Order of G to be \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (G)=|G| the cardinality of the underlying set of elements of G.
If the underlying set of elements of G is not finite, then we typically just assign \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (G)=\infty .

fr:title.text: Order of group element is order of subgroup generated by that element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Order of group element is order of subgroup generated by that element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group and g\in G. Then the order of g is the order of the subgroup generated by g, i.e., \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g)=\mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (\langle g\rangle ).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cancellation law
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 1.1.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let G be a Group, let a,b,c\in G. Then the following all hold:
If ac=bc, then a=b; and
If ca=cb, then a=b.

(1) Assume ac=bc, then multiply both sides on the right by c^{-1}, we see the left-hand side becomes (ac)c^{-1}=a(cc^{-1})=ae=a by assocativity and inverse, and the right-hand side becomes (bc)c^{-1}=b(cc^{-1})=be=b. Hence a=b.
(2) Assume ca=cb. Multiply both sides on the left by c^{-1} gives the result by similar reasoning as (1).

fr:title.text: Criteria for a group element being its own inverse

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for a group element being its own inverse

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group, let g\in G. Then g^{2}=e if and only if g^{-1}=g.

fr:title.text: Inverse of subset of a group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of subset of a group

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. We define the Inverse of A to be the subset A^{-1} of G equal to A^{-1}=\{a^{-1}\in G\mid a\in A\}.

fr:title.text: Product of subsets of a group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets of a group

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group, let A and B be subsets of G. We define their Product to be the subset AB of G equal to AB=\{ab\in G\mid a\in A,b\in B\}.
(1) This definition can be generalized to any nonempty multiplicative magma.
(2) There is no standard term for this product. Historically, van der Waerden called it the "complex product" (or "products of complexes"). Others have called it the Frobenius product.

fr:title.text: Product of subsets is nonempty iff subsets are nonempty

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets is nonempty iff subsets are nonempty

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. Then AB
eq \emptyset if and only if A
eq \emptyset and B
eq \emptyset .
(Equivalently, AB=\emptyset if and only if either A=\emptyset or B=\emptyset .)

fr:title.text: Product of subsets of a group is associative

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets of a group is associative

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A, B, C be subsets of G. Then A(BC)=(AB)C.

fr:title.text: Inverse of products of subsets is reverse product of inverses

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of products of subsets is reverse product of inverses

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A and B be subsets of G. Then (AB)^{-1}=B^{-1}A^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Product of subsets is distributive over union

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets is distributive over union

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A, B and C be subsets of G. Then A(B\cup C)=(AB)\cup (AC) and (A\cup B)C=(AC)\cup (BC).

fr:title.text: Product of subsets is distributive over intersection

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of subsets is distributive over intersection

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A, B and C be subsets of G. Then A(B\cap C)=(AB)\cap (AC) and (A\cap B)C=(AC)\cap (BC).

fr:title.text: Multiplying a subset of a group by a group element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplying a subset of a group by a group element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let g\in G be an element of G. Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G.

html:ol.html:li: We define gA to be the subset of G equal to gA:=\{g\}A
We define Ag to be the subset of G equal to Ag:=A\{g\}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Equivalently, x\in gA iff there is an a\in A such that x=ga; and x\in Ag iff there is an a\in A such that x=ag.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. A Subgroup of G is a group H such that its underlying set of elements is a subset of the set of elements of G, and the binary operator of H is the same as the binary operator of G restricted to H.
When H is a subgroup of G, we write H\leq G.
When H\neq G, we say H is a Proper Subgroup of G and write H\mathrel {<} G.
Let G be a Group. The Improper Subgroup of G is the subgroup H=G.
Some older texts distinguish "the improper subgroup of G" from "the group G" by writing \Omega _{G} for the improper subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Criteria for a subset to be a subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for a subset to be a subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 2.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group, let H\neq \emptyset be a nonempty subset of G. If for any x,y\in H we have xy^{-1}\in H, then H forms a Subgroup.
Furthermore, if H is finite, then it suffices to check that H is closed under multiplication (i.e., for any x,y\in H we have xy\in H).
If x=y, then xx^{-1}=e\in H contains the identity element.
For any x\in H, we have ex^{-1}=x^{-1}\in H, so H is closed under inverting elements.
For any x,y\in H, we have y^{-1}\in H, so x(y^{-1})^{-1}=xy\in H, which means H is closed under its binary operator.
Hence altogether H forms a subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Subgroups with the same sets are equal to each other

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroups with the same sets are equal to each other

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let H_{1} and H_{2} be Subgroups of G. If H_{1} and H_{2} have the same set of elements, then H_{1}=H_{2}.
Let G be a group. Then the Trivial Subgroup of G is the subgroup \mathbf {1}_{G} consisting of only the identity element: for any x, we have x\in \mathbf {1}_{G} if and only if x=e.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Torsion subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Exercise 2.1.6

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be an Abelian group. We define the Torsion Subgroup of G to be the Subgroup H=\{g\in G\mid \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g)<\infty \}.
Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G and K\leq G be Subgroups of G. Then the intersection H\cap K is a [strict] subgroup of G.
We can check H\cap K=K\cap H.
Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G, H_{2}\leq G, and H_{3}\leq G be Subgroups of G. Then (H_{1}\cap H_{2})\cap H_{3}=H_{1}\cap (H_{2}\cap H_{3}).

fr:title.text: Intersection of a family of subgroups is a subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of a family of subgroups is a subgroup

Let G be a Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We define the Left Cosets of H to be the family of subsets of G equal to \{gH\subseteq G\mid g\in G\}.
Let G be a Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We define the Right Cosets of H to be the family of subsets of G equal to \{Hg\subseteq G\mid g\in G\}.
Let G be a Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We define the Index of H to be the Cardinal number [G : H] equal to the cardinality of the left cosets of H.
(1) This is also equal to the cardinality of the right cosets of H.
(2) When G is a finite group, this is a natural number. More generally, when there are only finitely many left cosets of H, the index of H is a natural number.
Let G be a finite Group, let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. Then the product of index of H with the cardinality of H equals to cardinality |G|=[G : H]|H|.

Let G be a Group, let S\subseteq G be a subset of elements of G. Then we define the Subgroup Generated by S to be the subgroup \langle S\rangle such that S\subseteq \langle S\rangle and for any subgroup H\leq G such that S\subseteq H we have \langle S\rangle \leq H.

fr:title.text: Subgroup generated by a set is smallest subgroup containing that set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroup generated by a set is smallest subgroup containing that set

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group, let S\subseteq G be a subset of G. Then \langle S\rangle =\bigcap \{H\leq G\mid S\subseteq H\}.

fr:title.text: Subgroup generated by empty set is trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroup generated by empty set is trivial

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let S\subseteq G be empty S=\emptyset . Then the subgroup generated by S is \langle S\rangle =\langle \emptyset \rangle =\mathbf {1}_{G} the Trivial Subgroup of G.

Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G and H_{2}\leq G be Subgroups of G. We define the Frobenius Product of H_{1} with H_{2} to be the subset H_{1}H_{2} of G equal to H_{1}H_{2}=\{h_{1}h_{2}\in G\mid h_{1}\in H_{1}, h_{2}\in H_{2}\}. We stress this is not a subgroup.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This operator usually doesn't have a standard name. The only place I have seen it called "the Frobenius product" is in Adolfo Ballester-Bolinches, Ramon Esteban-Romero, and Mohamed Asaad's Products of Finite Groups (Walter de Gruyter, 2010, pg 1). In van der Waerden's Algebra, this was called the "product of complexes" or "complex product" (terminology which Kurzweil and Stellmacher use in their Finite Group Theory on page 6 of the English edition, right before proposition 1.1.5).

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Then the Lattice of Subgroups of G consists of all possible Subgroups of G, whose join is given by H\vee K=\langle HK\rangle the subgroup generated by the Frobenius product, and whose meet is given by H\wedge K=H\cap K the intersection of subgroups (which is a subgroup).

fr:title.text: Conjugation of an element by an element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of an element by an element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let a and b be elements of G. The Conjugate of a by b is the element a^{b}:=b^{-1}ab of G.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b,g\in G be elements of G. If a^{g}=b^{g}, then a=b.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of identity element is identity element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of identity element is identity element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let g\in G be an element of G. Then 1_{G}^{g}=1_{G}.

fr:title.text: Any element which is a conjugate of the identity must be the identity

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any element which is a conjugate of the identity must be the identity

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G be elements of G. If a^{b}=1_{G}, then a=1_{G}.

fr:title.text: Conjugating an element with respect to identity element is the given element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugating an element with respect to identity element is the given element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let a\in G be an element of G. Then a^{1_{G}}=a.

fr:title.text: Conjugating an element with respect to itself is the element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugating an element with respect to itself is the element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let a\in G be an element of G. Then a^{a}=a.

fr:title.text: Composing conjugation is conjugation of products

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing conjugation is conjugation of products

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let a,g,h\in G be elements of G. Then (a^{g})^{h}=a^{gh}.

fr:title.text: Conjugate of power is power of conjugate

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugate of power is power of conjugate

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G be elements of G. Let n\in \mathbb {Z} be an integer. Then (a^{n})^{b}=(a^{b})^{n}.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G be elements of G. We say a is conjugate to b if there exists an element g\in G such that a=b^{g}.

fr:title.text: Any element is conjugate to itself

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any element is conjugate to itself

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let a\in G be any element of G. Then a is conjugate to a.
This follows from Conjugating an element with respect to itself is the element.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G. If a is conjugate to to b, then b is conjugate to a.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b,c\in G. If a is conjugate to to b, and if b is conjugate to c, then a is conjugate to c.

Taking Conjugation is a transitive relation together with Any element is conjugate to itself and Conjugation is a symmetric relation means that the predicate "is conjugate to" forms an Equivalence relation.
Consequently, we will be able to say "a and b are conjugate" instead of caring especially about the ordering of arguments to the predicate.

fr:title.text: Conjugacy classes are either disjoint or equal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugacy classes are either disjoint or equal

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Hence the sets \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (a) and \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (b) are equal.
