Let G be a Group. We define the set of Conjugacy Classes of G to be the set \{\mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (g)\subseteq G\mid g\in G\}.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of subset by a subset

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of subset by a subset

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. We define A^{B}=\{a^{b}\in G\mid a\in A,b\in B\} to be the Conjugate of A by B.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of a subset by an element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of a subset by an element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. Let b\in G be an element of G. We define A^{b}=\{a^{b}\in G\mid a\in A\} to be the Conjugate of A by b.
Equivalently, using Conjugation of subset by a subset, we see A^{b}=A^{\{b\}}.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of an element by a subset

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of an element by a subset

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let a\in G be an element of G. Let B\subseteq G be a subset of G. We define a^{B}=\{a^{b}\in G\mid b\in B\} to be the Conjugate of a by B.
Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. We define the predicate A is conjugate to B to mean there exists a g\in G such that A=B^{g}.

fr:title.text: Any subset is conjugate to itself

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any subset is conjugate to itself

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. Then A is conjugate to itself.

fr:title.text: Conjugate subsets forms a symmetric relation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugate subsets forms a symmetric relation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets of G. If A is conjugate to B, then B is conjugate to A.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This means we can speak of "A and B are conjugate" or mix up the ordering of arguments in this predicate freely and wildly.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let A\subseteq G, B\subseteq G, and C\subseteq G be subsets of G. If A is conjugate to B, and if B is conjugate to C, then A is conjugate to C.

Let G be a Group, let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. Then we define the Conjugacy Class of A to be the family of subsets \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (A) of G equal to \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (A):=\{A^{g}\subseteq G\mid g\in G\}.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of a subgroup by an element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of a subgroup by an element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. Let g\in G be an element of G. Then we define the Conjugation of H by g to be the subgroup H^{g} of G such that its underlying set is given by the conjugation of the subset by g; i.e., for any a\in G, we have a\in H^{g} if and only if there is an h\in H such that a=h^{g}.
Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G and H_{2}\leq G be Subgroups of G. We define the predicate H_{1} is conjugate to H_{2} to mean there exists a g\in G such that H_{1}=H_{2}^{g}.
Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G be a Subgroup. Then H is conjugate to H.

fr:title.text: Conjugation of subgroups is a symmetric relation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation of subgroups is a symmetric relation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G and H_{2}\leq G be Subgroups of G. If H_{1} is conjugate to H_{2}, then H_{2} is conjugate to H_{1}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We will now be able to say "H_{1} and H_{2} are conjugate" or mix up the arguments willy-nilly.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let H_{1}\leq G, H_{2}\leq G, and H_{3}\leq G be Subgroups of G. If H_{1} is conjugate to H_{2}, and if H_{2} is conjugate to H_{3}, then H_{1} is conjugate to H_{3}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This means that, along with Conjugation is a reflexive relation and Conjugation of subgroups is a symmetric relation, conjugation of subgroups forms an Equivalence relation.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We define the Conjugacy Class of H to be the collection \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (H) of subsets of G such that: for any object x, we have x\in \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (H) if and only if there exists a subgroup K\leq G such that x=K and H is conjugate to K.
We should prove this is a well-defined notion.

Existence: The collection of subgroups may be formed by looking at the elements of \mathcal {P}(G) which may be given a subgroup structure. We may then use Set builder notation to form the conjugacy class of H.
Uniqueness: immediate.
Let G be a Group. Let N\leq G be a Subgroup of G. We say N is Normal if for each g\in G we have N=N^{g}.
If further N\neq G, we say N is a Proper Normal subgroup of G.
We will write N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G to indicate N is a normal subgroup of G, and N\mathrel {\triangleleft } G to indicate N is a proper normal subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Every group has a normal subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every group has a normal subgroup

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Then \mathbf {1}_{G} is a Normal subgroup of G (thus allowing us to use "normal" as an adjective).

We want to prove: for any g\in G we have \mathbf {1}_{G}^{g}=\mathbf {1}_{G}. Let g\in G. Then for any x\in \mathbf {1}_{G}^{g} we see x=1_{G}^{g}=1_{G}. Hence x\in \mathbf {1}_{G}. Hence \mathbf {1}_{G}^{g}=\mathbf {1}_{G}.

fr:title.text: Intersection of normal subgroups is normal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of normal subgroups is normal

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let N_{1}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G and N_{2}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be Normal subgroups of G. Then N_{1}\cap N_{2} is a normal subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Every subgroup of a commutative group is normal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every subgroup of a commutative group is normal

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Abelian group. Let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G. Then H is a Normal subgroup of G.
Since G is commutative, g^{h}=g for all g,h\in G. Then H^{g}=\{h^{g}=h\mid g\in G\}=H. Hence the result.

fr:title.text: Product of normal subgroup with group element is commutative

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of normal subgroup with group element is commutative

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. For any a\in G, we have aN=Na.

fr:title.text: Left cosets of normal subgroup are also right cosets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left cosets of normal subgroup are also right cosets

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. Then any left coset of N is also a right coset of N. That is to say, we may just speak of "cosets of N" since all left cosets are right cosets of N.
Immediately follows from Product of normal subgroup with group element is commutative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Centralizer of a subset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group, let A be a subset of G. Then the Centralizer of A is the subgroup C_{G}(A)=\{g\in G\mid \forall a\in A\ldotp gag^{-1}=a\} consisting of all elements of G which commutes with every element of A.

Let G be a Group, let a\in G be an element of the group. We define the Centralizer of a to be the Subgroup C_{G}(a) of G whose underlying set equals C_{G}(a)=\{g\in G\mid ag=ga\}. Observe this is the same thing as C_{G}(a)=C_{G}(\{a\}) the centralizer of the singleton \{a\}.
Let G be a Group.

html:ol.html:li: Let a\in G be an element, let B\subseteq G be a subset. We say a Centralizes B if for each b\in B we have ab=ba. In other words, a\in C_{G}(B) is an element of the centralizer of B.
Let A\subseteq G and B\subseteq G be subsets. We say A Centralizes B if every element a\in A centralizes B; i.e., A\subseteq C_{G}(B) is a subset of the centralizer of B.
Let H\leq G be a Subgroup of G, let B\subseteq G be a subset. We say H Centralizes B if every h\in H centralizes B. In other words, H\leq C_{G}(B) is a subgroup of the centralizer of B.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In the preceding three definitions, we may replace B with a subgroup K\leq G or an element b\in G.

Let G be a Group. We define the Center of G to be the Subgroup Z(G) of G consisting of all elements which commute with all of G: for any z\in G, we have z\in Z(G) if and only if for every g\in G we have zg=gz.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could define this more generally for any nonempty multiplicative magma, in which case it would be a submagma.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Existence: We see that 1_{G}\in Z(G) since 1_{G}g=g=g1_{G}.
We also see for any x,y\in Z(G) and any g\in G we have (xy)g=x(yg)=x(gy)=(xg)y=(gx)y=g(xy) which means Z(G) is closed under multiplication.
We also see for any x\in Z(G) and g\in G that x^{-1}g=((x^{-1}g)^{-1})^{-1}=(g^{-1}x)^{-1}=(xg^{-1})^{-1}=gx^{-1} which implies x^{-1}\in Z(G).
Hence Z(G) has a group structure induced from G.
Uniqueness: Subgroups with the same sets are equal to each other.
Let G be any Group. Then its center Z(G) is a Normal subgroup of G.
Let z\in Z(G) and g\in G. Then z^{g}=g^{-1}zg=zg^{-1}g=z which implies Z(G) is a normal subgroup.
Let G be any Group. Then its center Z(G) is a commutative Subgroup of G.
Let x,y\in Z(G). Then xy=yx since every element of the center commutes with any element of the group. Hence Z(G) is commutative.
Similarly, for any elemen g\in G, we can define the Normalizer of g to be N_{G}(g):=N_{G}(\{g\}) the normalizer of the singleton \{g\}.
And if H\leq G is a Subgroup, then we define the Normalizer of H to be the subgroup N_{G}(H) which is just the normalizer of the underlying set of H.
Let G be a Group. Let B\subseteq G be a subset of G.

html:ol.html:li: Let a\in G be an element. We say a Normalizes B if a^{-1}Ba=B; in other words a\in N_{G}(B).
Let A\subseteq G be a subset of G. We say A Normalizes B if every element of A normalizes B.
Let H\leq G be a subgroup of G. We say H Normalizes B if every element of H normalizes B.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We can replace B with a subgroup K\leq G and the definition of "normalizes" generalizes accordingly; and we can replace B with an element b, and the definition "normalizes b" is just a synonym for "normalizes \{b\}".

fr:title.text: Normal subgroups have their normalizer be the entire group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Normal subgroups have their normalizer be the entire group

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a [strict] Group, let H\leq G be a [strict] Subgroup of G. Then H is a Normal subgroup of G if and only if its Normalizer N_{G}(H)=G.

fr:title.text: Product of elements in a nonempty magma

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of elements in a nonempty magma

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M be a nonempty multiplicative magma (i.e., a set equipped with a multiplication operator with no properties imposed). Let (a_{i})_{i=1,…,n} be a finite sequence of elements of M. We define the Product of (a_{i}) to be the element \prod ^{1}_{i=1}a_{i}=a_{1} and for any k+1\leq n+1 \prod ^{k+1}_{i=1}a_{i}=\left (\prod ^{k}_{i=1}a_{i}\right )a_{k+1}. So generically \prod ^{n+1}_{i=1}a_{i}=((((a_{1}a_{2})a_{3})…)a_{n})a_{n+1}.
Let G be a Group. Let a,b\in G be elements of G. We define their Commutator to be the element [a,b] of G equal to [a,b]:=a^{-1}b^{-1}ab.
Caution: Many group theorists prefer defining the commutator [a,b]=aba^{-1}b^{-1} which is more useful in Lie groups.

Let G be a Group. We define the Commutator Subgroup (or Derived Subgroup) of G to be the subgroup G' of G such that G'=\langle \{[a,b]\in G\mid a,b\in G\}\rangle . In other words, it is the subgroup generated by the set of all commutators of all elements of G.
Other notation for this subgroup includes [G,G].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group Morphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G and H be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a function. We say \varphi is a Group Morphism (or just Morphism) if it preserves multiplication, i.e., for any g_{1},g_{2}\in G we have \varphi (g_{1}g_{2})=\varphi (g_{1})\varphi (g_{2}).
Let \mathbb {F} be a Field, let n\in \mathbb {N}. The determinant \det \colon \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F})\to \mathbb {F}^{\times } is a Group Morphism.
This follows from Properties of the determinant, specifically property (8), and elements of \mathop {\textrm {GL}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {F}) have nonzero determinant.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This generalizes to any commutative unital ring or even ringoid instead of \mathbb {F}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G and H be Groups, let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. If 1_{G} is the identity element of G and 1_{H} is the identity element of H, then \varphi (1_{G})=1_{H}.
We see \begin {align}1_{H}\varphi (1_{G})&=\varphi (1_{G})\\ &=\varphi (1_{G}1_{G})\\ &=\varphi (1_{G})\varphi (1_{G})\end {align} and then the Cancellation law gives the result.

fr:title.text: Group morphism preserves inverse of element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group morphism preserves inverse of element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G and H be Groups, let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. Let 1_{G} be the identity element of G and let 1_{H} be the identity element of H. If g\in G is any element of G, then \varphi (g^{-1})=\varphi (g)^{-1}.
We see that \begin {align}\varphi (g^{-1})\varphi (g) &= \varphi (g^{-1}g)\\ &= \varphi (1_{G})\\ &= 1_{H}\end {align} then multiplying both sides on the right by \varphi (g)^{-1} gives the result.

fr:title.text: Composing group morphisms yields a group morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing group morphisms yields a group morphism

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G_{1}, G_{2}, and G_{3} be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G_{1}\to G_{2} and \psi \colon G_{2}\to G_{3} be Group Morphisms. Then their composition \psi \circ \varphi \colon G_{1}\to G_{3} is a group morphism.

Let G and H be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. We define the Kernel of \varphi to be the subgroup \ker (\varphi ) of G such that its underlying set equals \{g\in G\mid \varphi (g)=e\}.
Existence: We see that \ker (\varphi ) is closed under multiplication since for any x,y\in \ker (\varphi ) has \varphi (xy)=\varphi (x)\varphi (y)=ee=e which means xy\in \ker (\varphi ).
We also see that for any x\in \ker (\varphi ) that \varphi (x)=e=e^{-1}=\varphi (x)^{-1}=\varphi (x^{-1}) which means x^{-1}\in \ker (\varphi ). So \ker (\varphi ) is closed under inverting elements.
Hence \ker (\varphi ) is a group and its underlying set is a subset of G.
Uniqueness: by Subgroups with the same sets are equal to each other.

Let G and H be Groups, let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. We define the Image of \varphi to be the subgroup \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi ) of H equal to \mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi )=\varphi (G).

fr:title.text: Image of subgroup under morphism is a subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Image of subgroup under morphism is a subgroup

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G_{1}, G_{2} be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G_{1}\to G_{2} be a Group Morphism. Let H\leq G_{1} be a Subgroup of G_{1}. Then \varphi (H)\leq G_{2} the image of H under \varphi is a subgroup of G_{2}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group Isomorphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G and H be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. We say \varphi is a Group Isomorphism (or just Isomorphism) if it is bijective and has an inverse function which is a also a group morphism.
When G=H, we say \varphi is a Automorphism of G.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphic groups
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G and H be Groups. We typically say G and H are Isomorphic if there exists a Group Isomorphism between them. This is reflexive since the identity function is an automorphism.

fr:title.text: Quaternion group isomorphic to subgroup of \GL _{2}(\CC )

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quaternion group isomorphic to subgroup of \GL _{2}(\CC )

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The isomorphism is given by sending A\mapsto j and B\mapsto k, then AB\mapsto i.
Let G and H be two Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. If \varphi is bijective, then \varphi is an isomorphism.

Let G be a Group, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. We define the Quotient Group G/N to consist of left cosets of N and the binary operator is given by (gN)(hN)=(gh)N for any g,h\in G. The inverse element of gN is g^{-1}N.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is well-defined because Left cosets of normal subgroup are also right cosets.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. We define the Natural Morphism of N to be the surjective group morphism n_{N}\colon N\to G/N sending g\in N to gN.

The three (sometimes four) isomorphism theorems are important, but no one agrees with how to enumerate them: the first isomorphism theorem is usually the same, but all bets are off for the remaining isomorphism theorems.
These isomorphism theorems may be traced back to Emmy Noether's Abstrakter Aufbau der Idealtheorie in algebraischen Zahl- und Funktionenkörpern (1927).

Let G_{1} and G_{2} be Groups, let \varphi \colon G_{1}\to G_{2} be a Group Morphism. Then there exists an isomorphism \psi \colon G_{1}/\ker (\varphi )\to G_{2} such that \psi \circ n_{\ker (\varphi )}=\varphi .

Let G be a Group. Let B\leq G be a Subgroup of G, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. If M\leq B is a subgroup of B, then we will denote (M)_{B} for M\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } B as a normal subgroup of B.

Let G be a Group. Let B\leq G be a Subgroup of G, let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a [strict] Normal subgroup of G. Then \frac {\langle BN\rangle }{(N)_{\langle BN\rangle }}\cong \frac {B}{B\cap N}.

Let G be a Group. Let N\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be a Normal subgroup of G. Let M\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G and J\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G be [strict] Normal subgroups of G. If J = N/(M)_{N} and M\leq N, then \frac {G/M}{J}\cong G/N.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G and H be Groups. We define the Product Group G\times H whose underlying set is the Cartesian product of two sets of the sets underlying G and H, whose binary operator is given by (g_{1},h_{1})(g_{2},h_{2})=(g_{1}g_{2},h_{1}h_{2}) and the identity element is 1_{G\times H}=(1_{G},1_{H}).

fr:title.text: Product of quotient group with denominator is not isomorphic to the given group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of quotient group with denominator is not isomorphic to the given group

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {Z}_{4} be the set of integers modulo 4. This is a commutative group. Let \mathbb {Z}_{2} be the set of integers modulo 2. This is a subgroup of \mathbb {Z}_{4} (just look at the subgroup generated by [2]).

Then the quotient group \mathbb {Z}_{4} / \mathbb {Z}_{2}\cong \mathbb {Z}_{2} is isomorphic to \mathbb {Z}_{2}. But (\mathbb {Z}_{4} / \mathbb {Z}_{2})\times \mathbb {Z}_{2}\not \cong \mathbb {Z}_{4}.

Let \mathcal {F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i\in I} be an indexed family of groups. For any group G and for any family of Group Morphisms \varphi _{i}\colon G\to F_{i}, there exists a unique morphism \varphi \colon G\to \prod \mathcal {F} such that for each i\in I we have \pi _{i}\circ \varphi =\varphi _{i} where \pi _{i}(x)=x_{i} is the projection onto the i^{\text {th}} factor of the product group \pi _{i}\colon \prod \mathcal {F}\to F_{i}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This reflects how morphisms contain all the interesting information about constructions.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Let I\subseteq \mathbb {N} be I=\{1,…,n\}. Let \mathcal {F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i\in I} be an indexed family of subgroups of G. If for each i\in I we have F_{i}\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } G is a Normal subgroup of G, and if and the Frobenius Product of Subgroups F_{1}F_{2}(…)F_{n}=G as sets, and if for each j\in I we have F_{1}(…)F_{j-1}\cap F_{j}=\emptyset , then F_{1}\times …\times F_{n}\cong G.
In this situation, we typically call G the Internal Direct Product of \mathcal {F}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of groups
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Exercise 5.1.17

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. We say G is Simple if the only normal subgroups of G are \mathbf {1}_{G} and G itself.
In other words, G is simple if and only if the only proper normal subgroup of G is trivial.

Let G be a Group. A Composition Series of G is a finite sequence H_{i} of subgroups of G such that \mathbf {1}_{G}=H_{0}\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{1}\mathrel {\triangleleft }…\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{n}=G, where H_{i}\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{i+1} for each i=0,…,n-1, and in particular H_{i+1}/H_{i} is Simple.
Note: There is no requirement that H_{i} is a normal subgroup of G except for when i=n-1.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For any group G, either there exists a nontrivial proper Normal subgroup N\mathrel {\triangleleft } G or it doesn't. If it does, then we can ask about the Quotient Group G/N and N. If G/N is simple, then we turn our attention to proper normal subgroups of N. We can repeat this questioning, and this gives us a composition series for G as a way of "breaking up" G.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. If \mathbf {1}_{G}=H_{0}\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{1}\mathrel {\triangleleft }…\mathrel {\triangleleft } H_{n}=G, and \mathbf {1}_{G}=K_{0}\mathrel {\triangleleft } K_{1}\mathrel {\triangleleft }…\mathrel {\triangleleft } K_{m}=G, are two Composition Seriess for G, then m=n and there exists a permutation \pi \in S_{n} such that H_{j+1} / H_{j}\cong K_{\sigma (j) + 1} / K_{\sigma (j)}.
In other words, the Composition Series for a group is unique.
Proof by induction on \min (m,n).
Base case: if \min (m,n)=1, then G is Simple, hence any other composition series is of length 1 and the unique subquotient is G.
Inductive argument: This is rather lengthy, I'll return to it.
Let G be a Group, let X be a set. A Left Action of G on X is a function \alpha \colon G\times X\to X such that:

html:ol.html:li: Identity: for all x\in X, \alpha (1_{G},x)=x; and
Compatibility: for all g,h\in G and for all x\in X, \alpha (g,\alpha (h,x))=\alpha (gh,x)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Note: usually we write g\cdot x instead of \alpha (g,x) when the action is unambiguous.

(1) We have a more general notion of an "action" of a group on an object depend on the kind of morphisms on the object. For example, a group acting on a vector space will have g\cdot - be a linear transformation of the vector space when we fix g\in G.

(2) We have a closely related notion of a "representation" of a group. Historically this emerged in a confused and haphazard way, describing several variations like a Permutation representation or a linear representation. Category theory clarified this as an object X and a group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (X). This may be viewed as a "curried" form of a group action.
Let G be a Group, let X be a set. A Right Action of G on X is a function \alpha \colon X\times G\to X such that:

html:ol.html:li: Identity: for all x\in X, \alpha (x,1_{G})=x; and
Compatibility: for all g,h\in G and for all x\in X, \alpha (\alpha (x,g),h)=\alpha (x,gh)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Note: usually we write x\cdot g instead of \alpha (x,g) when the action is unambiguous.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: If \alpha is a right action of G on X, then we may construct a left action \lambda of G on X by \lambda (g,x)=\alpha (x,g^{-1}). The identity property holds. The compatibility property: \begin {align*}\lambda (g,\lambda (h,x)) &=\alpha (\alpha (x,h^{-1}),g^{-1})\\ &=\alpha (x,h^{-1}g^{-1})\\ &=\alpha (x,(gh)^{-1})\\ &=\lambda (gh,x)\end {align*} as desired. For this reason, it suffices to study the left action of a group.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a group. We define the Automorphism Group of G to be the [strict] group \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (G) consisting of all automorphisms of G and the binary operator is composition.

fr:title.text: Action of a group on another group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Action of a group on another group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Sections 1.7 and 2.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G and K be Groups. An (Left) Action of G on K is an uncurried form of the group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (K); i.e., it's a morphism \alpha \colon G\times K\to K such that \alpha (g,k)=\rho (g)(k).
Usually we write g\cdot k instead of \alpha (g,k) for the left action of G on K, where g\in G and k\in K.
(1) This may be viewed as a special case of a Left group action.
(2) The \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (K) group morphism is called a Representation of G on the group K.

Let H and K be Groups. Let \varphi \colon K\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (H) be a group morphism. Then we define the Semidirect product of H with K with respect to \varphi to be the [strict] group H\rtimes _{\varphi }K consisting of all ordered pairs (h,k) where h\in H and k\in K and (h,k)(h',k')=(h\cdot \varphi (k)h',kk') is its binary operator.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The exact ordering of components of the ordered pair (h,k) doesn't matter; we could have (k,h) instead. The important thing is being consistent. The notation for (k,h) is usually K\ltimes _{\varphi }H.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Given: H and K be Groups.
We can study this further using group chomology (specifically the first group cohomology H^{1}(K,-)).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The terminology over the years here is rather confused, unfortunately. But it seems the way to think of it is that G is an extension of K by H. It is becoming more common to choose \widehat {K} instead of G for the extension of K.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If further \varphi is an isomorphism, then this describes an isomorphism of group extensions.
If \widehat {G} is not split, then we say it is a "nonsplit extension" of G.

Let p\in \mathbb {N} be a prime number. We see the extension of commutative groups, 0\to p\mathbb {Z} / p^{2}\mathbb {Z}\to \mathbb {Z} / p^{2}\mathbb {Z}\to \mathbb {Z} / p\mathbb {Z}\to 0, is the example of a nonspit extension.

fr:title.text: Criteria for an extension to be split

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for an extension to be split

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let \widehat {G} be an extension of G by H. Then \widehat {G} is split if and only if
there is a subgroup K\leq \widehat {G} such that \pi |_{K}\colon K\to G is an isomorphism; or
there exists a set of coset representatives \widehat {G}/H which is a subgroup; or
there is a subgroup K\leq \widehat {G} such that HK=\widehat {G} and H\cap K=\mathbf {1}_{G}; or
\widehat {G} is isomorphic to (as an extension) the semidirect product H\rtimes _{\varphi }G

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Permutation representation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 4.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let X be a set, let G be a Group. A Permutation Representation of G on X is a group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X) from G to the symmetric group of X.
When g\in G and x\in X, we write g\cdot x instead of \rho (g)(x). If there's ambiguity, we'll write \rho _{g}(x) to stress which representation we're using.

More generally, a Permutation Representation of G (without any mention of the representation space X) consists of a set X equipped with a group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is a "curried" form of a Left group action.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. Let x\in X. The Orbit of x is the subset G\cdot x of X equal to G\cdot x:=\{g\cdot x\in X\mid g\in G\}.

In physics, we describe the possible states for a given physical system using a configuration space. Symmetries occur to partition the configuration space into orbits, which describe "physically indistinguishable states". This intuition (an orbit describes "redundant states") is a great way to think of orbits of a group action.

Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. We say G acts Transitively (or that it's a Transitive Action) if there is only one Orbit of the action, i.e., for any x,y\in X there exists a g\in G such that g\cdot x=y.
Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. Let Y\subseteq X. We say Y is an Invariant Subset of X if G\cdot Y\subseteq Y, i.e., for each y\in Y and g\in G we have g\cdot y\in Y.
If there is some ambiguity about which group Y is invariant with respect to, we say Y is G-Invariant (or Stable under G or G-Stable).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This should evoke vague memories from intermediate linear algebra about Invariant subspaces.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group and X be a set. Suppose G acts on X. Let x\in X. The Stabilizer of x is the Subgroup (not necessarily normal) G_{x} of G equal to G_{x}:=\{g\in G\mid g\cdot x=x\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orbit-Stabilizer theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 4.1.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group and X be a nonempty set. Suppose G acts on X. Then for each x\in X, the cardinality of the Orbit G\cdot x is equal to the index of the Stabilizer of x, [G : G_{x}]=|G\cdot x|.

fr:title.text: Cosets of stabilizer are bijective with the orbits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cosets of stabilizer are bijective with the orbits

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We need to show \overline {f} is a well-defined Function. We see if aG_{x}=bG_{x}, then a^{-1}b\in G_{x} and by definition of the Stabilizer we see a^{-1}b\cdot x=x and therefore a\cdot x=b\cdot x. Therefore this is a well-defined function.
Reading this argument backwards, we establish \overline {f} is injective.
Since \overline {f} maps gG_{x} to g\cdot x, and g\cdot x can be an arbitrary element of G\cdot x, this means \overline {f} is surjective. Hence \overline {f} is bijective.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cayley's theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 4.2.4

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Then there is some symmetric group \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (G) and some subgroup H\leq \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits {G} such that G\cong H.
Moreover, if the order of G is n, then G is isomorphic to a subgroup of S_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation action
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.2

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. The Conjugation Action is an action of G on itself given by g\cdot x:=g^{-1}xg conjugation.

fr:title.text: Centralizer is fixed-point of conjugation action

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Centralizer is fixed-point of conjugation action

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Consider the Conjugation action of G on itself. Let g\in G. Then the centralizer C_{G}(g) of g is the set of all fixed-points of g under this action.
Let h\in C_{G}(g), then hg=gh and so g=h^{-1}gh=g^{h}. This means h is a fixed-point of g\cdot -. This argument holds backwards, which establishes the bijection.

fr:title.text: Index of centralizer is size of conjugacy class

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Index of centralizer is size of conjugacy class

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a Group. Consider the Conjugation action of G on itself. Let g\in G. Then the index of the centralizer C_{G}(g) of g is the cardinality of the Conjugacy class of an element of g: [G : C_{G}(g)]=|\mathop {\textrm {Cl}}\nolimits (g)|.
This follows immediately from Centralizer is fixed-point of conjugation action.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Class equation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 4.3.7

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a finite Group. Then |G| = |Z(G)| + \sum _{x}[G : C_{G}(x)] where the sum is taken over representatives from the representatives from distinct conjugacy classes disjoint from the center of G.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Nothing in the proof required G being specifically finite, but we end up with a decomposition of infinite cardinal numbers in the infinite G case...which is not as useful...

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let p be a prime number. Let G be a Group. We say G is a p-Group if there is some n\in \mathbb {N} such that |G|=p^{n}.
Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime, G be a Group. If |G|=p^{\nu } for some \nu \in \mathbb {N}, then |Z(G)|>1.

If |Z(G)|=1, then we need p\mathrel {\bigm |}[G : C_{G}(x)] for each coset representative x in each orbit, but this would require p\mathrel {\bigm |}|G|-|Z(G)|, i.e., p\mathrel {\bigm |} p^{\nu }-1 which contradicts our assumption.
Let G be a finite Group. If there exists a prime p\in \mathbb {N} and some r\in \mathbb {N} such that p^{r}\mathrel {\bigm |} |G|, then there exists a subgroup H\leq G such that |H|=p^{r}.
Let G be a finite Group. Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime. If p\mathrel {\bigm |}|G|, then there exists an element g\in G such that \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g)=p.
Let G be a Group. Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime. Let P be a p-subgroup of G. We say P is a Sylow p-Subgroup of G if p\nmid [G : P] (p does not divide [G : P]).

The Sylow theorems tell us about the existence and (non)uniqueness of Sylow p-subgroups of a finite group. The numbering differs book to book, so we will be following I. Martin Isaacs's Finite Group Theory in describing these theorems.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of a Sylow p-Subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: I. Martin Isaacs Finite Group Theory Theorem 1.7 (Sylow E-Theorem)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let G be a finite Group. Let p be a prime number. Then G has a Sylow p-subgroup.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This may be viewed as a partial converse of Lagrange's theorem.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: (Wielendt) Let |G|=p^{a}m where a\geq 0 and p\nmid m. Let \Omega =\{A\subseteq G\mid |A|=p^{a}\}. We see that G acts on \Omega by right multiplication. Since this is an action, \Omega is partitioned into orbits, and so |\Omega | is the sum of the orbit sizes.
But |\Omega |=\binom {p^{a}m}{p^{a}}\equiv m\not \equiv 0\pmod {p}, and so |\Omega | is not divisible by p. Then there exists some orbit \mathcal {O} such that |\mathcal {O}| is not divisible by p.

Let X\in \mathcal {O} and H=G_{X} be the Stabilizer of X in G. Then |\mathcal {O}|=|G|/|H| by the Orbit-Stabilizer theorem, and since p does not divide |\mathcal {O}| but p^{a} divides |G|, we must conclude p^{a} divides |H|, and in particular p^{a}\leq |H|.
Since H stabilizes X under right multiplication, we see if x\in X then xH\subseteq X, and then |H|=|xH|\leq |X|=p^{a}.
Since p^{a}\leq |H|\leq p^{a}, we must have |H|=p^{a}, and this is a Sylow subgroup of G as desired.

fr:title.text: Any p-subgroup is contained in a conjugate of a Sylow subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any p-subgroup is contained in a conjugate of a Sylow subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: I. Martin Isaacs Finite Group Theory Theorem 1.11

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let P be an arbitrary p-subgroup of a finite Group G, let S be any Sylow p-subgroup of G. Then there exists a g\in G such that P\subseteq S^{g}.

Let \Omega =\{Sx\mid x\in G\} be the set of right cosets of S in G. Observe |\Omega |=[G : S] is not divisible by p since S is a Sylow p-subgroup of G. We know G acts by right multiplication on \Omega , and so P acts too, and \Omega is partitioned into P-orbits. Since |\Omega is not divisible by p, there must exist some P-orbit \mathcal {O} such that |\mathcal {O}| is not divisible by p.

By the Orbit-Stabilizer theorem, |\mathcal {O}| is the index in P of some subgroup. It follows that |\mathcal {O}| divides |P|, which is a power of p. Then |\mathcal {O}| is both a power of p and not divisible by p, so the only possibility is |\mathcal {O}|=1. Since the members of \Omega are right cosets of S in G, we can consider g\in G such that \mathcal {O}=\{Sg\}.
Since Sg is alone in a P-orbit, it follows that it is fixed under the action of P, so Sgu=Sg for all u\in P. Then gu\in Sg, hence u\in g^{-1}Sg=S^{g}. Hence P\subseteq S^{g}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sylow p-Subgroups are conjugate
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: I. Martin Isaacs Finite Group Theory Theorem 1.12 (Sylow C-Theorem)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let S and T be Sylow p-subgroups of a finite Group G, then there exists a g\in G such that T=S^{g}.

This follows immediately from Any p-subgroup is contained in a conjugate of a Sylow subgroup taking P=T gives us T\subseteq S^{g} for some g. Since both S and T are Sylow p-subgroups, we have |S|=|T|=|S^{g}| we have T=S^{g} as desired.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This may be viewed as a "finite analog" of a result in Lie theory where all maximal tori are conjugate to each other.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sylow "Development" Theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: I. Martin Isaacs Finite Group Theory Theorem 1.14 (Sylow D-Theorem)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let P be a p-Subgroup of a finite Group G. Then P is contained in some Sylow p-subgroup of G.
In other words, Sylow subgroups are "maximal" among the p-subgroups of G.
Let S be a Sylow subgroup, by Any p-subgroup is contained in a conjugate of a Sylow subgroup there is a g\in G such that P\leq S^{g}. Since |S|=|S^{g}|, S^{g} is another Sylow p-Subgroup of G.

fr:title.text: Concluding remarks about introductory group theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Concluding remarks about introductory group theory

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Most "traditional" presentations of abstract algebra end their discussion about groups with the Sylow theorems.

It's difficult for me to present group theory this way, because group theory goes hand-in-hand with the representation of groups. But I promised to discuss the "traditional" treatment of group theory. Promises made, promises kept.

fr:title.text: Prefatory comments about traditional introduction to rings

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prefatory comments about traditional introduction to rings

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This is roughly the content of the Math 5B course at California Institute of Technology, organized from my notes from the course offered Winter Quarter 2018. These notes about rings would constitute the first half of the course (literally, the first 13.5 lectures out of the 27 lectures).

Most courses about rings are the same, but vary in level of rigor and detail. UC Davis's Math 150B course was not quite at this level of maturity, but it was close. But it is nowhere near the level of sophistication of UC Davis's graduate abstract algebra course content.

A (Unital) Ring consists of a set R equipped with
an Abelian group structure (R,+,0), and
a multiplication \star \colon R\times R\to R, and
(Optional) a "one" element 1\in R such that for any a,b,c\in R,
Associativity of addition: a+(b+c)=(a+b)+c
Additive identity element: a+0=0+a=a
Additive inverse: a+(-a)=0
Commutativity of addition: a+b=b+a
(Optional) Associativity of multiplication: a\star (b\star c)=(a\star b)\star c
(Optional) Unital property (i.e., multiplicative identity element): a\star 1=1\star a=a
Left distributivity of multiplication over addition: a\star (b+c)=(a\star b)+(a\star c)
Right distributivity of multiplication over addition (a+b)\star c=(a\star c)+(b\star c) Some rings don't have a multiplicative unit 1, in which case they are "nonunital rings". If we don't care about the existence of the multiplicative unit, we'll just speak of "rings".

We also don't require all rings to be associative (i.e., multiplication may or may not be associative). When it matters, we will speak of "associative rings" and "nonassociative rings", but by default we will assume rings as associative.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could define a unital ring as an Abelian group equipped with a monoid structure. The axioms for a unital ring would be satisfied automatically.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The integers \mathbb {Z} equipped with the usual addition and multiplication forms a Ring.
We need to prove that all 8 axioms are satisfied, but they are straightforward arithmetic.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The integers are the epitome of a ring.

fr:title.text: Rationals, reals, complex numbers are a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rationals, reals, complex numbers are a ring

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The rational numbers \mathbb {Q}, the real numbers \mathbb {R}, and the complex numbers form a ring.

Let R be a Ring, let n\in \mathbb {N}_{0} be any non-negative integer. We define the Matrix Ring \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R) to consist of all n\times n matrices equipped with Matrix Addition and Matrix Multiplication forms a ring.
Moreover, if R is unital, then \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R) is unital where its multiplicative identity is the identity matrix (and we see it satisfies the unit axioms).
Let R be a Ring. We say R is Commutative if its multiplication operator is a Commutative binary operator.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We see \mathbb {Z}, \mathbb {Q}, \mathbb {R}, and \mathbb {C} are commutative rings. But in general the Matrix ring is noncommutative since Matrix Multiplication is not commutative generally.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Quaternions is a generalization of the complex numbers, denoted as \mathbb {H} (after William Hamilton) consisting of t+ix+jy+kz where t,x,y,z\in \mathbb {R} are real numbers, where the imaginary "numbers" satisfy i^{2}=j^{2}=k^{2}=ijk=-1. It's not hard to deduce that jk=-kj=i ki=-ik=j ij=-ji=k Addition is given by (a+ib+jc+kd)+(t+ix+jy+kz)=(a+t)+i(b+x)+j(c+y)+k(d+z) and multiplication is given by \begin {align*} (a+ib+jc+kd)(t+ix+jy+kz) &=(at-bx-cy-dz)\\ &\quad +i(at+bx+cz-dy)\\ &\quad +j(ct-bz+cy+dx)\\ &\quad +k(az+by-cx+dt)\end {align*} This means the quaternions form a noncommutative ring.
(1) Quaternions turn out to be useful for 3d computer graphics.

(2) Although Springer's LaTeX macros uses \mathrm{i} for \sqrt {-1}, the conventions for the imaginary quaternions i, j, k varies wildly. Wikipedia uses bold symbols. Michael Kinyon told me on Bluesky that "Gibbs, in his 1881 Elements of Vector Analysis book (more like a pamphlet), just used the math typeface of his day for i,j,k."

From the past few examples, it should be clear that we should think of rings as number systems. In the 19th century, many Mathematicians explored different "number systems" by adding new "numbers" analogous to \mathrm {i}=\sqrt {-1}. This was how Hamilton invented the Quaternions. Many other rings were invented in this manner, and it's the best intuition to have in mind while we continue to study rings.
The set \mathbb {Z}[i]=\{x+\mathrm {i} y\in \mathbb {C}\mid x,y\in \mathbb {Z}\} forms a ring when equipped with addition and multiplication from the complex numbers.
Moreover, since multiplication of complex numbers is commutative, this forms a Commutative Ring.

Let \omega =\mathop {\textrm {exp}}\nolimits (\mathrm {i} 2\pi / 3)=(-1+\mathrm {i}\sqrt {3}) / 2. Then the set \mathbb {Z}[\omega ]=\{a+b\omega \in \mathbb {C}\mid a,b\in \mathbb {Z}\} forms a Commutative Ring when equipped with addition and multiplication from the complex numbers. These form the ring of Hurwitz integers.
Let A be an additive Abelian group. Then the set \mathop {\textrm {End}}\nolimits (A) of group morphisms ("endomorphisms") f\colon A\to A is a ring.
We see (f+g)(x)=f(x)+g(x) and (f\star g)(x)=(f\circ g)(x)=f(g(x)) are the binary operators for the ring.
This is called the Endomorphism Ring of A.

fr:title.text: Multiplication by Zero is Zero in a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Multiplication by Zero is Zero in a ring

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a (possibly non-unital) Ring. For any x\in R, we see 0\star x=0 and x\star 0=0.

We see from 0+0=0 that (0+0)\star x=0\star x. But distributivity rewrites the left-hand side as (0\star x)+(0\star x)=0\star x, then subtracting 0\star x from both sides gives us 0\star x=0 as desired.

Similarly, from 0+0=0 we see x\star (0+0)=x\star 0. Distributivity allows us to rewrite the left-hand side again as (x\star 0)+(x\star 0)=x\star 0 and then subtracting x\star 0 from both sides gives us x\star 0=0 as desired.
A unital Ring R with 1\neq 0 is called a Division Ring (or Skew Field) if for every nonzero element a\in R there exists a multiplicative inverse, i.e., there exists a b\in R such that ab=ba=1.
Let R be a unital Ring with 1\neq 0. If x\in R has a unique multiplicative two-sided inverse, then we will just denote it by x^{-1}.
Let R be a unital (possibly nonassociative) Ring. Let x\in R be an element of R. We say x is a Unit if it has a two-sided inverse x^{-1}\in R such that x^{-1}x=xx^{-1}=1.

fr:title.text: Inverse of one is one in a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of one is one in a ring

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a unital Ring. Then 1^{-1}=1 and (-1)^{-1}=-1 in R.
We see 1=1\star 1^{-1}=1^{-1} the first equality by definition of multiplicative inverse, the second equality by the unital property.

Similarly 1=(-1)\star (-1)^{-1} so then adding -1 to both sides gives us 0=1-1=(-1)\star (-1)^{-1}+(-1) and distributivity allows us to rewrite (-1)\star (-1)^{-1}+(-1)=(-1)\star ((-1)^{-1}+1)=0. So either -1=0 or (-1)^{-1}+1=0.
If (-1)^{-1}+1=0, then adding -1 to both sides gives us the result.

fr:title.text: Negation in a unital ring is multiplying by minus one

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Negation in a unital ring is multiplying by minus one

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a unital Ring. For any x\in R we have -x=(-1)\star x.
We see x+(-1)\star x=1\star x+(-1)\star x and then distributivity gives us x+(-1)\star x=(1-1)\star x=0\star x and from Multiplication by Zero is Zero in a ring we have the result.

Let R_{1} and R_{2} be Rings. We define their Product Ring R_{1}\times R_{2} to consist of the direct product of the underlying set of elements of R_{1} with R_{2}, equipped with the operations (a,b)+(c,d)=(a+c,b+d) and (a,b)(c,d)=(ac,bd). This forms a ring.
Moreover, if R_{1} and R_{2} are both commutative, then R_{1}\times R_{2} is commutative.
And if R_{1} and R_{2} are both unital, then R_{1}\times R_{2} is unital.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This generalizes to any indexed family of rings \{R_{i}\}_{i\in I}.

fr:title.text: Set of nonzero elements in a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of nonzero elements in a ring

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be an arbitrary Ring. Then the Set of Nonzero Elements of R is denoted by R^{*}:=\{x\in R\mid x\neq 0\}.

fr:title.text: Set of invertible elements of a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of invertible elements of a ring

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a unital (possibly nonassociative) Ring. We define the Set of Invertible Elements of R to be the set of elements with two-sided inverses: R^{\times }:=\{x\in R\mid \exists x^{-1}\in R\ldotp xx^{-1}=x^{-1}x=1\}. Furthermore, if multiplication is associative, then this forms a group.
This example generalizes to any n\geq 2 and any unital Ring R (with a single nonzero entry instead of 1 for non-unital rings).

fr:title.text: Ring of formal distributions has zero divisors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of formal distributions has zero divisors

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a Field (but it could be any commutative ring, however nice you want it). Let x be a formal variable. Consider the Ring of Formal Distributions \mathbb {F}[{[x,x^{-1}]}] which consists of generic formal power series like f(x)=\sum ^{\infty }_{n=-\infty }a_{n}x^{n}. Consider the specific function \delta (x)=\sum _{n\in \mathbb {Z}}x^{n} Then x\delta (x)=\delta (x) so (1-x)\delta (x). But 1-x\neq 0 and \delta (x)\neq 0, so \mathbb {F}[{[x,x^{-1}]}] has zero divisors.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This ring appears when studying Vertex Operator Algebras, a sort of formal model of 1-dimensional quantum field theories.

fr:title.text: Ring elements are either units or some kind of zero divisor

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring elements are either units or some kind of zero divisor

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a unital associative Ring, let x\in R be any arbitrary element of R. Then either x is a Unit or x is a Zero Divisor.

If x is a left zero divisor, then there is a y\in R such that xy=0. But if x were also a unit, then \begin {align*}0&=x^{-1}0\\ &=x^{-1}(xy)\\ &=(x^{-1}x)y\\ &=1y=y\end {align*} which contradicts the condition that y\neq 0 in the definition of a zero divisor.
The situation for x being a right zero divisor is similar.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: It is important to stress that the ring must be associative. The Sedonions are a nonassociative unital ring where nonzero elements have a multiplicative inverse and there are also zero divisors.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A Ring is called a Domain if it has no Zero Divisors.
An Integral Domain is a commutative Domain.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

html:ol.html:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").

fr:title.text: Integers modulo a prime form a field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integers modulo a prime form a field

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let p\in \mathbb {N} be a prime number. Then \mathbb {F}_{p}:=\mathbb {Z} / p\mathbb {Z} forms a Field.
Let us write \overline {n} for the element of \mathbb {F}_{p} corresponding to the equivalence class containing n\in \mathbb {Z}.
Claim 1: \mathbb {F}_{p} forms an Abelian group with addition and \overline {0}.
Claim 2: \mathbb {F}_{p} forms a commutative unital ring with multiplication and multiplicative identity \overline {1}.
Claim 3: Every nonzero \overline {n}\in \mathbb {F}_{p} has a multiplicative inverse.

Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let x\notin R be a formal variable (just a symbol, not a number). We define the Ring of Polynomials with coefficients R and in unknown x to be the ring R[x] consisting of formal polynomials which are finite sums p(x)=\sum ^{n}_{k=0}a_{k}x^{k} where a_{n}\neq 0, addition is done with the coefficients of each power, and multiplication is done using the Cauchy convolution product \left (\sum ^{m}_{j=0}a_{j}x^{j}\right )\left (\sum ^{n}_{k=0}b_{k}x^{k}\right )=\sum ^{m+n}_{k=0}\left (\sum ^{k}_{j=0}a_{j}b_{k-j}\right )x^{k}. Then this forms a commutative ring.
(2) We could generalize this to noncommutative R, but there are subtle issues which cause problems best left to be revisited in a graduate level algebra course.

Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. An n-dimensional Multi-Index is an n tuple \alpha =(\alpha _{1},…,\alpha _{n}) where each component \alpha _{i}\in \mathbb {N}_{0} is a non-negative integer.
We have the following operations defined:

html:ol.html:li: Componentwise sum and difference: \alpha \pm \beta =(\alpha _{1}\pm \beta _{1},…,\alpha _{n}\pm \beta _{n})
Sum of components |\alpha |=\alpha _{1}+…+\alpha _{n}
Factorial \alpha !=\alpha _{1}!(…)!\alpha _{n}!
If x=(x_{1},…,x_{n}) is a tuple of unknowns (or knowns), then x^{\alpha }=x_{1}^{\alpha _{1}}(…)x_{n}^{\alpha _{n}}

fr:title.text: Properties of degree of formal polynomials

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of degree of formal polynomials

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p,q\in R[x_{1},…,x_{n}] be nonzero formal polynomials. Then the following all hold:

html:ol.html:li: If R is an integral domain, then \deg (fg)=\deg (f)+\deg (g)

fr:title.text: Ring of formal polynomials with coefficients in integral domain forms an integral domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring of formal polynomials with coefficients in integral domain forms an integral domain

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be an Integral domain. Let x be a formal polynomial. Then the Polynomial ring R[x] is an integral domain.

Let R be a Commutative Ring, let x be a formal variable. We define the Ring of Formal Laurent Polynomials to be the ring R(x)=\{\sum ^{n}_{j=-k}a_{k}x^{k}\mid a_{j}\in R, a_{-k}\neq 0,a_{n}\neq 0, n,k\in \mathbb {N}_{0}\}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Caution: Terminology seems to vary wildly here. Some people reserve the term "Laurent polynomials" for the situation where n=\infty . I'm going to call these things Formal Laurent series and denote it by R(\mskip -3mu(x)\mskip -3mu) in analogy to R[{[x]}].

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let x be a formal variable. The Ring of Formal Power Series R[{[x]}] consists of all formal power series f(x)=\sum ^{\infty }_{n=0}a_{n}x^{n} with addition defined by matching powers of x: \left (\sum _{n}a_{n}x^{n}\right )+\left (\sum _{m}b_{m}x^{m}\right )=\sum _{n}(a_{n}+b_{n})x^{n} and multiplication defined by Cauchy convolution product \left (\sum _{n}a_{n}x^{n}\right )\left (\sum _{m}b_{m}x^{m}\right )=\sum _{n=0}\left (\sum ^{n}_{k=0}a_{n-k}b_{k}\right )x^{n}. This is a unital ring when R is unital.

Let R be a Ring. A Subring of R is a ring S such that S\subseteq R and 0\in S and +_{R}|_{S}=+_{S} and \star _{R}|_{S}=\star _{S}. In other words, every element of S is an element of R, and R's binary operators restricted to S coincide with S's binary operators.
If R is a unital ring and 1\in S, then we say S is a Unital Subring of R.
We see \mathbb {Z}\subseteq \mathbb {Q}\subseteq \mathbb {R}\subseteq \mathbb {C}\subseteq \mathbb {H} are subrings.
Let n\in \mathbb {N} and R be a Ring. Then some common subrings of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(R) include:

html:ol.html:li: Diagonal matrices form a subring
Upper-triangular matrices form a subring
Lower-triangular matrices form a subring

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Exercise: Do the collection of orthogonal matrices form a subring or not?
Exercise: Do the collection of unitary matrices form a subring of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(\mathbb {C}) or not?

Let R be a Ring. The Center of R is the subring Z(R) consisting of z\in R such that for all r\in R we have zr=rz and also (for non-associative rings) for all r,s\in R and for all z\in Z(R) we have z(rs)=(zr)s and r(zs)=(rz)s and (rs)z=r(sz). In other words, Z(R) consists of elements which commute and associate with all elements of the ring.
Uniqueness: If there are two possible centers, it's obvious they contain the same elements, which means they are equal to each other.

Existence: We see that the underlying set is nonempty and well-defined. We just need to show it is closed under addition and multiplication and contains 0\in Z(R)...well, 0r=0=r0 for all r\in R, so 0\in Z(R).
We see for any z,w\in Z(R) that for all r\in R, (z+w)r=zr+wr=rz+rw=r(z+w) which means z+w\in Z(R). So it's closed under addition
We see for any z,w\in Z(R) that for all r\in R, (zw)r=z(wr)=(wr)z=(rw)z=r(wz)=r(zw) which means zw\in Z(R). So it's closed under multiplication.
Taken together, this means there exists a well-defined center Z(R) which is a subring of R.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For associative rings R, we only need to check that zr=rz for all z\in Z(R) and for all r\in R, since it's associative.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Exercise: If R is unital, is 1\in Z(R) or not? Prove it.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring morphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R and S be Rings. We define a Ring Morphism (or just a Morphism if unambiguous) to be a function \varphi \colon R\to S such that:

html:ol.html:li: Additive: for any x,y\in R we have \varphi (x+y)=\varphi (x)+\varphi (y)
Preserves zero: \varphi (0_{R})=0_{S}
Multiplicative: for any x,y\in R we have \varphi (xy)=\varphi (x)\varphi (y)
Preserves one (when between unital rings): \varphi (1_{R})=1_{S} when there is a 1_{R}\in R and 1_{S}\in S

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Exercise: Do we really need \varphi (0)=0 or is this a consequence of additivity?
Exercise: Do we really need \varphi (1_{R})=1_{S} or is this a consequence of the multiplicative property?

fr:title.text: Inclusion of factor into direct product

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inclusion of factor into direct product

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Consider i\colon \mathbb {Q}\hookrightarrow \mathbb {Q}\times \mathbb {Q} defined by i(x)=(x,0). We claim i is not a Ring morphism.
We see that i(1)=(1,0)\neq (1,1) so i cannot possibly be multiplicative.

fr:title.text: Not all rings have morphisms between them

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Not all rings have morphisms between them

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let p\in \mathbb {N} be prime. Then there is no ring morphism \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}_{p}\to \mathbb {Z} from any finite field to the integers.

Assume there were a ring morphism. Then \varphi (1+(p-1))=\varphi (1)+\varphi (p-1) by additivity, but \varphi (1+(p-1))=\varphi (p)=\varphi (0)=0, so we must have \varphi (1)+\varphi (p-1)=0 which then implies 0=\varphi (1)+\varphi (p)-\varphi (1)=\varphi (p). But this means p=\varphi (\sum ^{p}_{i=1}1)=0 which is a contradiction.

fr:title.text: Identity function is a ring morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity function is a ring morphism

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring. Then \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{R}\colon R\to R is a Ring morphism.
Let R and S be Rings. Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then the following all hold:

html:ol.html:li: For any x\in R, \varphi (-x)=-\varphi (x)
For any x,y\in R, \varphi (x-y)=\varphi (x)-\varphi (y)
If R is unital, then either \varphi (1)=1 or \varphi (1)=0.
For any ring T and Ring morphism \psi \colon S\to T, we see \psi \circ \varphi \colon R\to T is a ring morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left ideal of a ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Left Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that
for any r\in R and x\in I we have rx\in I; and
for any x,y\in I we have x+y\in I.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could speak of ideals in more general settings, e.g., rings without negation.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right ideal of a ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Right Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that
for any r\in R and x\in I we have xr\in I; and
for any x,y\in I we have x+y\in I.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring. A (Two-Sided) Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that I is a left ideal and a right ideal of R.
Furthermore, when I\neq R we say I is a Proper (two-sided) ideal of R.

Some authors use the notation I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }R to indicate I is an ideal of R, as well as I\mathrel {\triangleleft }R for proper ideals, analogous to the notation used for Normal subgroups.
(1) For commutative rings, any left ideal is also a right ideal, and so we just speak of "ideals".
(2) "Ideal" originally described "ideal elements" adjoined to a ring, which are not "real".
(3) A two-sided ideal forms a Subring of R, same for one-sided ideals of R.

(4) Traditionally, the historic notation used to indicate we're working with ideals was to use fraktur letters (\mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b}, \mathfrak {c}, and so on). This was a horrible decision. Modern conventions use I, J, and variants using apostrophes or indices.

fr:title.text: Collection of ideals forms a set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Collection of ideals forms a set

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring. Then the collection of left/right/two-sided ideals of R forms a set.

Look at the set \mathcal {I}=\{I\in \mathcal {P}(R)\mid I\hbox { is an ideal}\}, where "is an ideal" means the subset is a left/right/two-sided ideal (depending on what the reader wants). This is clearly a subset of \mathcal {P}(R), which means \mathcal {I} is the set sought.
Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left/right/two-sided ideals of R. Then we define their sum to be the left/right/two-sided ideal I+J=\{a+b\in R\mid a\in I,b\in J\}.

Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left/right/two-sided ideals of R. Then we define their product to be the left/right/two-sided ideal consisting of all possible finite linear combinations IJ=\{a_{1}b_{1}+…+a_{n}b_{n}\in R\mid n\in \mathbb {N},a_{i}\in I,b_{i}\in J\hbox { for }i=1,…,n\}.

Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. We define the Kernel of \varphi to be the (two-sided) Ideal \ker (\varphi ) of R defined by: for all x\in R we have x\in \ker (\varphi ) if and only if \varphi (x)=0.
Let R be any Ring. Then \{0\} gives us an Ideal of R called the Trivial Ideal.

fr:title.text: Intersection of ideals is an ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of ideals is an ideal

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be left (resp., right, two-sided) ideals of R. Then I\cap J is a left (resp., right, two-sided) ideal of R.

fr:title.text: Division rings have trivial left ideals

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Division rings have trivial left ideals

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let D be a Division ring. Then the only left ideals of D are D itself and the Trivial ideal.
Let I be a left ideal of D. Let x\in I be nonzero x\neq 0. Then there exists a x^{-1}\in D such that x^{-1}x=1\in I and then all of D is contained in I.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient Ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.3.6

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Ring and I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. Then the additive quotient group R/I is a ring under the following binary operators (r+I)+(s+I)=(r+s)+I and (r+I)(s+I)=(rs)+I for all r,s\in R.

Furthermore,
If R is commutative, then R/I is commutative.
If R is unital, then R/I is unital.

To prove well-definedness, we should prove R/I equipped with these operators form a ring (since existence and uniqueness follow from the quotient group). Specifically, that multiplication exists and satisfies the various axioms.
Let R be a Ring, let I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. The Canonical Morphism \pi \colon R\to R/I is defined by: for any a\in R, \pi (a)=a+I.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: There is no standard notation for the canonical morphism, and I was debating between \gamma (Greek lowercase "c" for "canonical") and \pi since it's a sort of projection.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R and S be Rings. A Ring Isomorphism from R to S is a Ring morphism \varphi \colon R\to S such that there exists a ring morphism \psi \colon S\to R satisfying \varphi \circ \psi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{S} and \psi \circ \varphi =\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{R}.
We say rings R and S are isomorphic (denoted R\cong S) if there exists a ring isomorphism \varphi \colon R\to S.
Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then \varphi is a Ring Isomorphism if and only if \varphi is bijective.
Let \varphi \colon R\to S be a Ring morphism. Then the following all holds:

html:ol.html:li: \ker (\varphi )\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is an Ideal of R
\mathop {\textrm {Im}}\nolimits (\varphi )\subseteq S is a Subring.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Canonical ring morphism of \ker (\varphi ) is the Ring Isomorphism being sought.
Let R be a Ring, let A\subseteq R be a Subring of R, and let I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. Then the following all hold:

html:ol.html:li: A+I\subseteq R is a subring
A/(A\cap I)\cong (A+I)/I with the isomorphism defined by a\mapsto a+I

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Only the first two results needs to be proven.
Let R be a Ring. Let I,J\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be Ideals of R. If I\subseteq J, then J / I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R / I and \frac {R / I}{J / I}\cong R / J.
Let R be a Ring. Then:

html:ol.html:li: A Left Principal Ideal of R is the ideal Ra=\{xa\in R\mid x\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.
A Right Principal Ideal of R is the ideal aR=\{ay\in R\mid y\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.
A Left Principal Ideal of R is the ideal RaR=\{xay\in R\mid x,y\in R\} for some fixed a\in R.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: When R is a Commutative Ring, all three notions coincide and we write (a) for the principal ideal generated by a.
Let R be a Ring.

html:ol.html:li: A Maximal Right Ideal is a proper right ideal I\subset R such that for any other right ideal J\subseteq R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.
A Maximal Left Ideal is a proper left ideal I\subset R such that for any other left ideal J\subseteq R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.
A Maximal (Two-Sided) Ideal is a proper ideal I\mathrel {\triangleleft } R such that for any other ideal J\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R, if I\subseteq J then either I=J or J=R.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: When we drop the condition that I is proper, then we have a Quasi-Maximal left/right/two-sided ideal.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For commutative rings R, all three notions coincide.

fr:title.text: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.12

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then M is Maximal ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/M is a Field.
Let R be a Commutative Ring. An ideal P\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is Quasi-Prime if for any a,b\in R such that ab\in P, then either a\in P or b\in P.
If P\mathrel {\triangleleft } R is a proper quasi-prime ideal, then we say it is a Prime Ideal.

(1) This notion does not generalize to noncommutative rings. If we tried "naively" looking for ideals of \mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{2}(\mathbb {C}) which are prime, then we will not find any. It remains an open problem how to define prime ideals for noncommutative rings.

(2) Hungerford Algebra Exercise 9(b) in Section III.2 asks the reader to prove: if D is a division ring and R=\mathop {\mathrm {Mat}}\nolimits _{n}(D), then R has zero divisors and so the trivial ideal (0) is prime, which means R\cong R/(0) but R is not an integral domain. This is because R is not a commutative ring. (See? Things get really weird when trying to think about prime ideals in a noncommutative ring.)

fr:title.text: Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.13

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let P\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then P is Prime Ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/P is a Integral domain.

fr:title.text: Maximal ideals of a commutative ring are prime

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Maximal ideals of a commutative ring are prime

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. If M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R is a Maximal ideal, then M is prime.
Assume M is maximal. Then R/M is a field (since Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field). Then R/M is a Field. Then M is prime by Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of Maximal Ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Krull's Idealtheorie in Ringen ohne Endlichkeitsbedingung (1929)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R\neq 0 be a nonzero unital Ring. Then there exists a maximal ideal M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R of R.

The typical proof offered is: consider the lattice of proper ideals of R ordered by inclusion. There exists at least one ideal of R (e.g., the Trivial ideal). Then Zorn's lemma implies there exists a maximal element of a chain containing the trivial ideal.
(1) This is often called "Krull's theorem", which is unfortunate because there are about a half dozen different results in ring theory called "Krull's theorem".

(2) The condition that R is unital is really critical. For example, we can turn any additive group G into a nonunital ring by defining multiplication x\star y=0 for all x,y\in R. There is no maximal ideal for such a ring

(3) In ZF set theory, this theorem implies the axiom of choice. Hodges first proved it. For a review of this, see Alexei Entin's "Maximal Ideals in Commutative Rings and the Axiom of Choice" (arXiv:2404.18351).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal generated by a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.4

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a unital Ring with 1\neq 0. Let A\subseteq R be any subset of R. Then the Ideal Generated by A is the ideal \langle A\rangle of R equal to \langle A\rangle = \bigcap _{A\subseteq I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R}I. This is the smallest ideal of R containing A.
When A=\{a_{1},…,a_{n}\} is a finite set, then we just write \langle a_{1},…,a_{n}\rangle or (a_{1},…,a_{n}) for the ideal generated by A.
Exercise: What is \langle \emptyset \rangle the ideal generated by the empty set?
Exercise: If we allow R to be a nonunital ring, then is the ideal generated by a set still well-defined?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fields only have trivial ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.9(2)

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Then R is a Field if and only if its only ideals are 0 and R.
We see R is a field iff every nonzero element is a unit (by definition of a field).
(\Longrightarrow ) If R is a field, then every nonzero ideal contains a unit, which means that R is the only nonzero ideal.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose the only ideals of R is the trivial ideal and R itself. Let u be any nonzero element of R. Then (u)=R so 1\in (u). Hence there must be some v\in R such that 1=vu (i.e., u is a unit). Therefore every nonzero element of R is a unit, hence R must be a field.

fr:title.text: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 7.4.10

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then any nonzero Ring morphism from \mathbb {F} into another ring must be an Injective function.
The Kernel of a ring morphism is an ideal. The kernel of a nonzero morphism is a proper ideal, hence must be 0 by Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principal Ideal Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.4

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An Integral domain R is called a Principal Ideal Domain if every ideal is principal (i.e., generated by a single element).

Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain. Let I_{1},I_{2},…,I_{n},I_{n+1},…,\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be ideals of R such that I_{1}\subseteq I_{2}\subseteq …\subseteq I_{n}\subseteq I_{n+1}\subseteq …. Then there exists an n_{0}\in \mathbb {N} such that I_{n}=I_{n_{0}} for all n\geq n_{0}.
Let I=\bigcup _{n}I_{n}. If a,b\in I, then a\in I_{m} and b\in I_{n} for some m,n\in \mathbb {N}. If p=\max (m,n) and a,b\in I_{p}, then a\pm b\in I_{p}\subseteq I. So I forms a group under addition.
For any a\in I, there is an n\in \mathbb {N} such that a\in I_{n}. Then for any r\in R we have ra\in I_{n}\subseteq I. So I forms an ideal.

Since R is a Principal Ideal Domain, there exists an a_{0} such that I=(a_{0}). But then there exists an n_{0} such that a\in I_{n_{0}}. So I=(a_{0})\subseteq I_{n_{0}}. Then for any n\geq n_{0}, we have I\subseteq I_{n_{0}}\subseteq I_{n}\subseteq I which proves the chain of ideals stabilizes.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euclidean Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 8.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An Integral domain R is said to be a Euclidean Domain if there is a norm N\colon R\to \mathbb {N}_{0} such that for any two elements a,b\in R with b\neq 0, there exists elements [the quotient] q\in R and [the remainder] r\in R such that a=qb+r and r=0\quad \hbox {or}\quad N(r)<N(b).
The integers form a Euclidean Domain when given the absolute value as its norm N(x)=|x|. This is because of the Division algorithm.

fr:title.text: Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Every ideal in a Euclidean Domain is principal: if R is any Euclidean domain and I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R with 0\neq I, then I=(d) where d is any nonzero element of I of minimum norm.

Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let a,b\in R with b\neq 0. We say a is a Multiple of b if there exists some x\in R such that a=bx. In this case, we say b divides a (or b is a divisor of a) and we write b\mathrel {\bigm |} a.

Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let a,b\in R with b\neq 0. A Greatest Common Divisor of a and b is a nonzero element d\in R such that:
It's a common divisor: d\mathrel {\bigm |} a and d\mathrel {\bigm |} b, and
It's greatest: for any d'\in R such that d'\mathrel {\bigm |} a and d'\mathrel {\bigm |} b, we have d'\mathrel {\bigm |} d. A greatest common divisor of a and b is denoted by \gcd (a,b) or (abusing notation) by (a,b).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This isn't necessarily unique, we may have multiple distinct greatest common divisors of a and b. When it is unique, we call the ring a GCD Domain (and it turns out to be an Integral domain).

fr:title.text: Existence and Uniqueness of GCD in Euclidean Domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence and Uniqueness of GCD in Euclidean Domains

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Let R be a Euclidean Domain. Then for any nonzero a,b\in R,
There exists a unique d\in R (up to unit multiple) such that d=\gcd (a,b); and
there exists x,y\in R such that \gcd (a,b)=ax+by.

This follows by performing Euclid's algorithm; i.e., we repeatedly apply the division algorithm to find b=q_{1}a+r_{1}, a=q_{2}r_{1}+r_{2}, r_{1}=q_{3}r_{2}+r_{3}, …, r_{n+1}=q_{n+3}r_{n+2}. Then r_{n+2}=\gcd (a,b) since:
(1) (r_{n+2})\subseteq (a,b)
(2) (a,b)\subseteq (r_{n+2})
Hence by (1) and (2) and since Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains, we have (r_{n+2})=(a,b) which implies the result.
Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be a nonzero element which is not a unit. We say p is Prime if whenever p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab then either p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b.
Exercise: Can this be generalized to a unital associative ring?

fr:title.text: Element is prime iff it generates a nonzero prime ideal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Element is prime iff it generates a nonzero prime ideal

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring where 1\neq 0, let p\in R. Then p is a Prime element if and only if (p) is a nonzero Prime Ideal.

(\Longrightarrow ) Let p be a Prime element. Then for any a,b\in R, \begin {align*}ab\in (p) &\iff \exists r\in R\ldotp ab=pr\\ &\iff p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab \hbox { iff }p\mathrel {\bigm |} a\hbox { or }p\mathrel {\bigm |} b\\ &\iff a\in (p)\hbox { or }b\in (p)\\ &\iff (p) \hbox { is a prime ideal}\end {align*}

(\Longleftarrow ) Let P=(p) be a nonzero prime ideal. For any a,b\in R, if p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab, then ab\in P, which implies a\in P or b\in P by definition of prime ideals. So we have p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b. Hence p is a prime element of R.
Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be a nonzero element which is not a unit. We say p is Irreducible if whenever d\mathrel {\bigm |} p, then we have either d=pu or d=u for some unit u\in R.
When p is not irreducible, we say it is Reducible.
Exercise: Can this be generalized to a unital associative ring?

Let R be a Commutative Ring, let p\in R be an element of R. Then p is irreducible if and only if its Principal Ideal (p) is a nonzero Maximal ideal among principal ideals (i.e., (p) may be a proper subideal of some ideal I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R where I may or may not be a proper ideal, just so long as I is not a principal ideal).

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume p is irreducible and assume (a) is a proper principal ideal of R (for some a\in R). Then \begin {align*} (p)\subseteq (a) &\iff p\in (a)\\ &\iff p=ab\hbox { for some }b\in R\\ &\implies a\mathrel {\bigm |} p\\ &\implies a=pu\hbox { or }a=u\hbox { for some unit }u\in R^{\times }\end {align*} If a=u, then (a)=R which contradicts our assumption that (a) is proper.
If a=pu, then (a)=(p), hence (p) is maximal among proper principal ideals.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose (p) is maximal among principal proper ideals. We want to show p is irreducible. Suppose there exists some a\in R such that a\mathrel {\bigm |} p, which is equivalent to saying (a)\subseteq (p). Then either (a)=R (which means a\in R^{\times } is a unit) or (a)=(p) (which implies a=pu for some unit u\in R^{\times }). In both cases, we have p is irreducible.

fr:title.text: Irreducible elements are prime in a PID

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible elements are prime in a PID

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be Principal Ideal Domain, let p\in R be an element of R. If p is irreducible, then p is prime.
Assume p is irreducible. Then we proved this is equivalent to (p) is maximal among principal ideals. Then (p) is prime, which implies p is prime.

fr:title.text: Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be an Integral domain, let p\in R be a nonzero element p\neq 0. If p is a prime element of R, then p is irreducible.

Let p\in R^{*} be a nonzero element. Assume p is prime. Then for any a,d\in R such that p\mathrel {\bigm |} ad we have \hbox {either }p\mathrel {\bigm |} a\hbox { or }p\mathrel {\bigm |} d, by definition of prime.
Now, by definition of irreducible, suppose we had some d\in R d\mathrel {\bigm |} p. We will show that either d=pu or d=u for some unit u\in R.

Since d\mathrel {\bigm |} p, this means there exists an a\in R such that p=ad. Since p is prime and p\mathrel {\bigm |} p (i.e., p\mathrel {\bigm |} ad), this means p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} d. Then we argue by cases.

Case 1: p\mathrel {\bigm |} a. Then there exists a b\in R such that a=pb. But then p=ad=(pb)d, using distributivity and subtraction gives us (1-bd)p=0. Then bd=1 since p\neq 0. Then d is a unit, since R is an integral domain. Then p is irreducible by definition.
Case 2: p\mathrel {\bigm |} d. The argument is similar to case 1.

Let R be Commutative Ring, let p\in R and q\in R be irreducible elements of R. We say p and q are associates (or p is associated to q) if there exists some unit u\in R^{\times } such that p=uq. This is a predicate, so it's well-defined.
This is a symmetric predicate since u^{-1}\in R^{\times } so we have u^{-1}p=q, too.
It's not too hard to see it's really an Equivalence relation.
Some examples we have seen before:

html:ol.html:li: The integers \mathbb {Z} form a unique factorization domain.
The Gaussian integers \mathbb {Z}[i]\subseteq \mathbb {C} form a unique factorization domain.

The integers \mathbb {Z}[\sqrt {-5}] adjoined with \sqrt {-5} is not a unique factorization domain, since 6=2\dot 3=(1+\sqrt {-5})(1-\sqrt {-5}) are two possible factorizations. Hell, \mathbb {Z}[\sqrt {-5}] isn't even a Principal Ideal Domain.
